reviewText:
TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:An old game (by the time I wrote this review) but a great game nonetheless.

As you might know, this is a Star Wars game based on the Clone Wars era where you are the leader of an elite Clone Commando Unit tasked with some of the most dangerous and most critical missions in service of the Galactic Republic.

PROS:+ Story: -Amazing story that places you not in the eyes of a skillful Jedi or a powerful Sith, but in the boots of Clone Troopers fighting the war. The game delivers in terms of story with its superior voice acting by Temuera Morrison (Jango Fett) as well and the various personalities of your squad mates really adds to the experience.

+ Squad Mechanics: -You cannot Rambo (go solo) this game, mainly because the squad is mandatory, BUT also because the game is brutal as hell (like most old FPS games). Enemies are really hard to kill without your squad's support requiring the players to properly order their squads into position and direct their fire when necessary.

+ Graphically pleasing despite its age: -Released on 2005, this game carries a dated visual design, but pleasing nonetheless. Animation is good and the atmosphere is immersive. (I simply love the HUD in this game)

+ Sound: -One of the greatest OST I have ever heard. (Vode An is the greatest of these OST)

+ Gameplay: -Lengthy campaign without getting boring: There is always action around the corner.

CONS:- Squad AI is a bit limited: -Although the AI, for the most part, is intelligent and is far more useful than some of the other AI partners in modern games, I feel as though a bit more could have been done. They follow command well enough.

- Bugged Graphic setting in terms of Bump Mapping: -Remained unfix to this day. (can be turned off in the options menu though)

Additional Note:The game is linear (corridor shooting), from start to finish. THIS IS NOT A BAD THING PEOPLE. Not all games need to be open world, specially if the game, such as this one, is trying to properly tell the story in a progressive fashion giving the player a sense of direction and purpose.

CONCLUSION:MUST BUY and MUST OWN for any Star Wars fan or First Person Shooter fans.

---------------------------------------------------------

Miyumi's Review Corner (MIRECO)

reviewText: People often complain about the stone-faced, bald and monotomous space marines in videogames; how they're an extremely overused template and stifle the development of round characters. Republic Commando puts an interesting spin on this complaint: It gives you four clones; four space marines. That's where the complaining ends.\n\nRepublic Commando is a squad based shooter set in the Star Wars universe during the Clone Wars. You play Delta 38 Boss"
date: leader of a highly specialised and extremely elite squad of Clones. You're bred with a great affinity for your clone bretheren. Your squad is as much a part of your arsenal as your special rifles and armour. Repulic Commando translates this premise to gameplay in an absolutely incredible way. You can 'direct' your squad to perform tasks while you hold off the enemy. Or you can work on the objective while you let them hold the line. The surprise in this comes from their intelligence. More often than not
recommended: CPU allies are less than helpful. Not the Clone Commandos; they are in a league of their own. They take

reviewText:
In this game, you play as Commando Delta 38 (Boss/Leader).
The game follows the story of three missions throughout Delta Squad's career in the Separatist Crisis.
From fighting alongside wookies to getting your face drilled by a scavenger droid, you lead your squad to complete objectives your normal, mass produced, counterparts could/cannot.

The game and story is nice, I loved it and maybe you will too. This is from the soldier's perspective as to the usual jedi perspective. The game plays pretty damn smooth on PC. I haven't had any real game-breaking problems. The game is old enough to even play on lower-end laptops. You get to actually order your squad to do things (ex.When you issue the Search and Destroy order, they become aggressive and move ahead even if you're looking around, You can order them to set demolition charges on objectives to progress or you could order them to secure the area and plant the demolition charge yourself. You can even send them to sniper/anti-armor positions as well as turrets.)

If you lose all your health, you get downed and the game doesn't end until your entire squad is downed. So while you're downed you could either tell them to maintain current orders (ex. search and destroy) or order the closest squad member to revive you. There's also the option to load the last save while you're downed. There's also quicksaves, I hotkeyed mine to F1 and F3 because I can screw things up a lot.

I don't think you can really get through this game without ordering your squad around. You take quite a bit of damage, even on medium difficulty. Just for future reference, don't run infront of your squad while they're firing a sniper or a anti-armor grenade. Bad things happen. . .

All in all this game was great for it's time and pretty short if you know what you're doing. I just REALLY wish there was a sequal just because of the ending. . .

reviewText:
The moment you boot up Republic Commando is the moment your realize this isn't your usual Star Wars games.

Presented in a darker, militaristic tone, you're placed in the shoes of Boss, a freshly manufactured clone, whose the leader of a commando squad of four. The opening epitomizes the message of the game, that you're a soldier and you have to rely on your squad-mates- as a side-note, look up during the short scene on Kimino, that's the attention to detail this game has. The art-style is harsher and the droids have an threating growl to their voices (♥♥♥♥ those whiny voices Lucas went with). It certainly feels unique since it uses its own soundtrack instead of constantly using John Williams pieces as a crutch. Stylistically, the game is beautiful, with a absolutely rocking soundtrack that knows when to throw in those vocals and drum-beats. Graphically, it's a 2005 game and console port, at 60 fps and proper lighting it's better than the original xbox version for sure. However, I believe it's the art-style instead of the textures that carries the visual direction.

The actual gameplay harkens back to Rainbow Six with how you use your AI partners to clear levels and focus fire. Some of my favorite aspects of the game are the fact that you can 'prep' for battle. You can order a sniper to sit back or have one of your guys bombard the enemy from grenadier nest. Now you can only do this through context sensitive actions, but it's more a feature of the level design that rewards player thought than a you can only proceed after using a laser-designated airstrike on these helpless sand people".

The AI is very compentent too. They will require revival
date: but that's only on the hardest sections of the game. I never felt like they were idiotic
recommended: and actually they keep up with you extremely well. It's no F.E.A.R
voteText: the AI never failed me on the several play-throughs I've had both past and present.\n\nAugmenting this squad is your own weaponry. The standard blaster is honestly a peashooter to me

reviewText:
Tl'dr version:
One of the best Star Wars games out there. To this day, an underrated and often overlooked part of the evolution of squad based shooters; also included is a fantastic soundtrack.
Great, (for the most part) A.I, and likeable squad mates make this short, but engaging ride all the sweeter


Elaborated version:
I often find that people have a tendency to harp on about SW: Battlefront and KOTOR a little bit too much. They were great games, (especially the latter) but I found them to be deeply flawed games. SW: Republic Commando, while flawed in some ways, manages to pull everything together in a much more satisfying way. This is obviously due to it's genre, and the nature of the mission structure. Not a thing is out of place. This comes at price however; the mission structure is disjointed to say the least, and the story is bare bones. However you'll get the feeling this was deliberate, as just like in real combat, and especially if you're a 'slightly less expendable' clone, you'll not be kept up to the date with the war as a whole. The game will take it tacitly that you know the Star Wars lore already and fling references to the films at you without guilt or trepidation. For a avid SW fan this wont be a problem, I unfortunately found myself lost at some points in the dialogue.

The mechanics are just as you expect from a Squad shooter; intuitive, tight, and easy to control. The PC version runs great with a M&C set up, but a controller is also possible. It might be necessary to have button mapping software however, as the games age breaks the controls.
You squad mates don't need you to hold their hand, and can perform simple tasks without you needing to give the order. However, they will occasionally rush in a 'no win scenario' and be dropped in matter of seconds under a hail of plasma fire. This will happen to you over and over, and their really is no way to stop it happening. This does have the unintended use of keeping aggro off you, while you attend to other matters.
The game features the modern invent system of the FPS. That is to say. You're limited to two normal weapons, 1 special weapon, and multiple attachments to your assault rifle, thus giving the weapon variety a much needed boost. There is a weapon for every scenario.

Now, onto the soundtrack. As a avid collector of game Soundtracks, this would have a proud spot on my list. In short; it's fantastic. A mixture of choral, and star wars symphony tropes mixed together to create a chilling, but engaging and epic theme. Definitely worth getting on soundtrack.

Finally, onto the negatives, and they are surprisingly few.
The game is no looker, and is really showing it's age as of 2015. However, over a decade on and it's vista's are still rather eye catching, especially the later missions on Kashyyyk.
Also, while I said the A.I was great; that was for last decade. Now not so much. Your squad mates will get stuck on geometry and regularly fail to revive you, even if their aren't any enemies in the area. This is all forgiven however by the amazing squad dynamic of banter that is constantly being thrown around. Very rarely will you actually care what your objective is, but you'll genuinely like and care for your squad as the game progresses, and you feel like this is a family.


Final thoughts:
By no means a looker, and to modern audiences this game might feel slightly lost in why this game was so great back in the day, however I still recommend giving it a try if it comes on sale.
Everything is here:

• Great Combat
• Great Characters
• Great Soundtrack
• Reasonable length.

*Be aware however, the MP for the game has been shut down.*

reviewText:
One of the better Star Wars games out there. I despise the prequel trilogy, yet I still found this game to be quite good. It's an FPS where you play as the leader of an elite squad of commandos sent on the toughest of jobs.

You can position your squad members, each one is supposedly skilled at different tasks, and it's mostly just blasting your way through droids and bugs in caverns, facilities, and space ships. You get the typical weapons--shotguns, pistols, sniper, rifle, etc. mostly in star-wars-style laser blasting form.

It's about ten hours long, and it's a pretty good campaign with some neat set-pieces. The squad members have some fun personalities and the voice work is solid. Since it's an older game, there are no iron sights, so that might be hard to get used to. The graphics hold up well, although I do believe it lacks widescreen. There are some compatibility issues, so you might need to take a look at the forums if you run into problems.

reviewText: On the timeline of great FPS games, Republic Commando sadly lurks in the shadow of the classics, but outdoes them in many respects. This Metroid Prime-inspired and slightly darker take on the Star Wars mythos puts you right in the shoes of a squad of covert Republic infiltrators carrying out a series of increasingly tense missions in tightly designed levels. A cohesive package of sound, graphics, and story that coalesce to form one of the ofter overlooked masterpieces of the genre.

reviewText:
No nonserious review this time, I can't think of anything.
And here's my little info thing. Star Wars: Republic Commando is a tactical first-person shooter taking place in the prequel trilogy, or the Rise of the Empire Era, during a period of three to four years known as The Clone Wars, which is infact, my favorite part of Star Wars. Yes, get mad at me for liking the prequels. You play as Boss, a clone commando who leads Delta Squad, a squad of commandoes. There is Scorch, the explosives expert, Fixer, what you could call a hacker I guess, and Sev, the sniper.
Time for the review part.
Pros:
+ First off, THE MUSIC. It's amazing!
+ The graphics are quite good.
+ The gameplay is decent, better than some other first person shooters.
+ It has a good storyline, even though it's short.
+ Good voice acting
+The characters are good.

Cons:
- Widescreen support has to be edited in.
- Campaign is short.
- Cliffhanger ending.

Star Wars fan? Pick it up!
Get's a 9/10 from me!
voteText: 94 of 103 people (91%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I remember playing this game way back on the original Xbox. It's not through rose-colored glasses that I say this is the greatest squad-based shooter I've ever played.

Let's start with the atmosphere. It's spot on. Any casual Star Wars fan will recognize most of the enemies and locations. The level and character designs are grittier than what you see in the movies, and that fits the tone perfectly. The HUD is one of the best I've ever seen, because YOU SEE THE BORDERS OF YOUR HELMET! Such a simple design choice affects your immersion immensely.

So everything around you is cool. What about the combat? This game FEELS great. The modular weapons system is genius.  The squad commands are easy to learn but hard to master. The difficulty is pleasantly challenging; don't expect yourself to be repeating tons of levels, but do expect to be constantly searching for health and ammo. The weapons feel rewarding to use, and above all, the squad-based combat is amazing. You FEEL bad-♥♥♥. You FEEL like it's you four protagonists against the world. And you WANT to take 'em all on.

Your three Clone Commando compatriots, Scorch, Fixer, and Sev, are exceptional AI companions (especially for 2005). They are effective in combat, respond to commands instantly, and generally don't make the kind of dumb decisions that make you rage at AI companions. They don't talk much, but you can still feel personality emanating from them.

On the note of character, the one category where this game falters is story. You know where you are, and you know why. You have objectives. But that's about it. The characters don't change over time. There are no plot twists. There is an instance of tragic loss (I won't spoil it for you), and it hits you hard. But there is room for improvement in that area.

Besides the story, what other improvements could be made? I won't comment on the graphics, because this game is coming up on 10 years old, but I will say they've aged well. The only thing that springs to mind is the level design. Don't get me wrong, the levels are designed fine, but it gives away what's to come. When you see a spot where you can issue a sniping command, you know there's enemies directly ahead. Health and ammo are always located directly behind large groups of enemies. It's textbook old-fashioned level design, but you always know what's coming.

One final point: because this is an older game, a 1920x1080 aspect ratio is not an option it offers. It's a minor detail, but an important one.

In conclusion, ten years later, this is still an incredible game. Although the story is never going to be a selling point, everything else about this game is great. It feels like you're taking a first-person trip through the summer action film spectacular that Star Wars never had. I highly recommend it to anyone who puts gameplay ahead of graphics. Amongst the vast troves of LucasArts treasures, this gem certainly shines bright.

reviewText:
Yes, the first few missions may be dull: Slice this, snipe that and so on. But that isn't the point. The point is, you need to work as a team. Sure, I may be a Star Wars fan myself but this doesn't affect my opinion on this fantasic game. To the people who say the graphics make up the game entirely, just do yourself a favour and don't play a single game for the rest of your life. Sure, the graphics in this game aren't up to scratch with today's standards but they sure were back in the good days of 2005. To be honest, I think they're great!

The gameplay and story line is simply amazing. It brings you back to Geonosis, Kashyyk, an abandoned Republic Cruiser and a few other places. I don't think there is another Commando game out there that is based on Star Wars. But if there is, this has got to be one of the best around. I spent heaps of time playing Star Wars Battlefront 1 & 2 and let me tell you, those are amazing games too. The squad that you play with is also very responsive and helpful (unlike in many other games). They'll do what you tell them to do. No questions asked. Unless they are under heavy fire and it is protocol-wise required to defeat the enemy first (goddammit just revive me already haha). Scorch really does keep the squad alive with his 'jokes', athough he can say it the wrong times.

But too bad Lucas Arts and Pandemic have left the Star Wars games, they were doing a fantastic job. Anyway, overall this is a fantastic game and I hope it won't be forgotten. If you are looking for a multiplayer, try going to Star Wars Battlefront 2. That is also an amazing game. I'll give it 9.5/10. Buy it already if you haven't! Have fun! :)

reviewText:
Ever thought Rainbow Six getting into Star Wars? Well here it is. A very fun and rather short game perfectly fitting into the Star Wars Universe. Your team, Delta, is formed by 4 RC clone commandos:
-1138 (Boss, squad-leader, that is You)
-1262 (Scorch, demolitions)
-1207 (Sev, sniper)
-1140 (Fixer, tech expert)

It is rather great to give individual orders to this team simulating a spec op team behind enemy lines into a Star Wars universe. This feature gives the game uniqueness. For this reason I do recommend it to anyone who loves Star Wars.

Thanks for reading.

reviewText: Don't let my hours fool you, I've completed this game nearly 3 times over. This game is frankly one of the greatest Star Wars games out there. Republic Commando puts you in the boots of (you guessed it) a clone commando, with 3 squadmates. You travel to locations like Geonosis, Kashyyyk, and an abandoned Republic ship. This game focuses on squadwork, while you or another squadmate is arming a charge to get into a locked door, the other 3 are stopping the super battle droid shooting at you (which are actually kinda intimidating in this game). This is an older game, but you will still be impressed with the graphics to a degree, and at the not-as-expensive-as-98%-of-all-fps-shooters-out-there price of $10, I believe that this quality game is well worth your money!

reviewText:
-played for years not using steam-

My undisputed favorite game of all time. Amazing game-play and squad controls plus an immersive world create a memorable campaign leaving you longing for more. The worlds and characters you meet along the way are varied. Enemies have distinct faults you can exploit to defeat them. Voice acting and level design are both fantastic and add to the great campaign. Your squad has AI way ahead of its time and for once you don't grow tired of them. Instead you develop a weird sense of attachment to each of their unique personalities. Beyond being my favorite single player game it was also my go to for multiplayer* in which it molded arena combat and amazing maps to create a fantastic experience.

*multiplayer servers are down and there are many issues when trying to bypass that with the steam version.

Pros:
Game-play
Voice acting
immersion
Squad
Characters
World/lvl design
enemies
plot

Cons:
Servers for multiplayer are down

9.75/10

reviewText: This game hold a unique place amongst the Star Wars games. There are no lightsabers, you don't have the force, you only have Delta Squad. The gunplay is fun, the gameplay is very interesting and challenging, and the AI is actually decent. In Republic Commando your squad of Commandos are not just fodder to absorb fire for you. They are good at killing, they can be deployed into a variety of tactical positions and be given a variety of orders, they get hurt, and they can be taken down. In the event you are taken down, they can actually help you up, which is pretty impressive. Another difference this game has from other Star Wars games is it's decidedly darker tone, as you aren't hanging out in the nicest of places. After all, you are a soldier and you are definitely in the ♥♥♥♥.\n\nI cannot reccomend this game enough to fans of both Star Wars and FPS games.
voteText: 33 of 35 people (94%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Republic Commando is a FANTASTIC game, one of the greatest Star Wars games ever made and unquestionably the best Star Wars first-person shooter ever made (I do not count Jedi Outcast or Jedi Academy, because the lightsabers kind of radically change those games to the point where they no longer really qualify). The squad AI is still incredibly good by today's standards, the characters are compelling and smartly-written, and the environments and story are original and creative.

But I cannot openly recommend getting this on Steam without some qualifying statements.

Republic Commando is an old game. A very old game. And it does not play nicely with newer computers. Problems with bumpmapping in the graphics can result in crashes, and trying to get it to run on a 64-bit Windows OS is a horrific struggle. If you have Windows 7 or 8 64-bit, Republic Commando may need to be sadly relegated to the history books. Hopefully your memories, if you got a chance to play it back in the day. You will likely not get another.

EDIT: Ever since I upgraded to Windows 10, it's worked perfectly. I don't know what changed, but I hereby retract the preceding paragraph. In the interests of transparency, I will leave it up, but the compatibility issues probably won't affect you anymore.

reviewText:
For coming out in 2005 this game still is a thrill to go back and relive the ultimate Clone Special Ops experience. You will be tasked with dealing with the most elite and discreet Republic operations, and leading a group of 4 (including yourself) elite Clone soldiers called Commandos.

To begin, the gameplay is really good for a 2005 game. The shooting action gets really intense in the latter part of the game, and you will have to learn how to manage your squads survival as well as your own. Get too caught up in keeping your squad fit, and your own health will fall and you will go unconscious. Focus too much on your own health and equipment, and your squad will be left without orders and ultimately end up dying. This ends up being a gameplay goal for you as you must balance the two in order to have a successful playthrough (unless you want to play on the easiest difficulty). Although this does end up becoming a problem when your squad completely goes against their own common sense and runs out into a crowd of a bunch of droids, guns blazing, and gets shot down within seconds. Your squad also tends to run in front of you as you're throwing a grenade, which is super annoying because it will take down your shields and your health, as well as your squad member's, and you will still have enemies firing at you. I also feel the game is a little bit too difficult as you will find yourself screaming at your monitor on the Normal difficulty setting. Perhaps the developers could have balanced the difficulties by adding a fourth one (easy would still be easy, add a normal, normal would be hard, and hard would be very hard). But still, the game is still enjoyable despite the setbacks of a few gameplay issues. The guns are also nice. Most of them have decent sounds (other ones being laughable), and they have a good difference in purpose and power. The grenades, with the exception of the flash-bang grenade, are all pretty useful. Although none stand out above the other in the department of usefulness as they're all pretty much the same: aim at your enemy and throw. But still, they're a decent touch.

The presentation is at an average level. With your standard graphics card you can max this game out, and the visuals won't look too bad. The textures are decent, and you won't really see any frame rate drop or texture pop-ins. The game overall has excellent environments that all differ from each other drastically. You'll go from fighting on the sandy and rocky world of Geonosis to the abandoned" Republic ship in a matter of hours. With the varied environments and average graphics with no presentation technical difficulties

reviewText: In Star Wars Republic Commando, you play as Delta Three-Eight, lead of Delta Squad. This means that you order your fellow brother around the various battlefields, keeping them alive- and developing a real connection with them throughout the game. Sev is the tough guy, always making remarks to boost the squad's confidence. You, the designated leader, have inherited Jango Fett's accent and his skills. Scorch, my favorite, is always there to make jokes and lighten the mood. Geonosis, the Assualt ship, and Kashyyyk are all wonderfully crafted and are great to explore if you are interested in them. The gunplay is great and commanding your fellow commandos is almost always flawless. The music is fantastic, some areas using the movies' music, and some areas (and main menu) using a darker score. The enemies are diverse and have their weaknesses. Some enemies are annoying, but most are fun and challenging to battle. You really see why clones are intimidated by Super Battle Droids and Droidekas and Spider Tanks, something that was never felt in Star Wars Battlefront II. Also, it has AWESOME breaching, hacking, and grenade gameplay. You also get a new perspective on various battles in the movies, such as the Battle of Geonosis and the Battle of Kashyyyk. I am a huge Episode I-III fan and think this is the second best Star Wars game of all time besides Star Wars Battlefront I/II. I have the first Republic Commando  book ready as well. So, what are you waiting for? Play it!

reviewText:
Finally, some external marketing of Star Wars that does the franchise perfect justice.
This game may be older, but it's one of the greatest and still relevant shooters I've played today.
Tired of the jedis? Or massive Battlefront-style unit management? Take control of Delta Squad: an elite group of clones who all have their own specialties to bring to the team, and personalities that play well off one another in the amsuing dialouge.
The shooting feels pretty good. Enemies die in a lot of visually pleasing and hilarious ways, keeping the good cartoon/serious balance Star Wars is known for. While there's a dissapointing variety of guns, the ones you have suit you very well.
As Delta Squad's leader, you take advantage of squad commands". Split up your three squad members to take up sniper positions

reviewText:
Even as an old game, it's simply brilliant and brilliantly simple.
Even on the easiest difficulty, it's extremely difficult.

Republic Commando takes place during my favorite point in Star Wars history, the Clone Wars, and provides an interesting story that provides a few layers of depth to the Grand Army of the Republic. Unlike most shooters, such as Battlefield and Child Online Daycare, your weapon isn't the strongest thing you have (in fact, it's kind of weak sometimes) - it's your squad. When presented with seemingly-unstoppable enemies such as droidekas and super battle droids, you'll need every single rifle aimed at the target. You cannot just blitz through the levels, like you can in most games. It requires a lot of skill and coordination, that both add up to make Republic Commando a very challenging game,  but also a really fun one.

reviewText:
In my opinion Star Wars Republic Commando has to be one of the best first-person shooters made to date. This is because:
1. The combat feels great! running at a group of droids firing away at you with just the right amount of accuracy to be a threat and then dispatching them one by one with your wristblade is one of the best experiences in gaming!
2. The Team. Your team is made up of 4 people (no spoilers, as you find this all out in the opening) you, the elite Delta 38, the sniper Sev (Delta 07), the hot headed demolitions expert scorch (Delta 62), and the trustworthy commando fixer (Delta 40). Your command over them is relatively limited as you only have 4 options, Search and destroy, Form up, Stay here and Do thing (sniper point, grenade point, breach door, hack, etc) Also if you die" your squad will carry on fighting until finished and then will revive you with half health (you can order them to revive you sooner but that often puts them in a very vulnerable spot).
3.The environments
date: without spoiling the game for you the envoronments range from full on battles with other troopers present to creepy environments with your enemies lurking around every other corner.\n4. The story. The story really attaches you mentally to your squad and by the end you'll be scolding scorch for shooting you in the back rather than cursing the AI
recommended: and there are some real moments of accomplishment in the story such as the end of the first "chapter". The ending is awesome too!.\nSo to sum up

reviewText: I can't get over how stunningly well this game holds up to the test of time.  I used to game away at Republic Commando when I was but a wee lad, though I never finished it because of that timed level at the end of the first act (let me just get it out of the way, that's probably the biggest doozy in this game).  If you can get past an occasional sharp difficulty curve through impressive strategy or dogged pursuit of your goals, you'll find this to be one of the most rewarding experiences you've ever had in a shooter.  It's polished, impressive, tense at parts, and will thrill you despite the limited mechanics.\n\nIn summary, singlehandedly the greatest shooter I've ever played, up to and including stuff like the Bioshocks and Battlefront. Get this game.

reviewText:
*PSA: Despite taking place in the prequel era, Republic Commando does a good job of steering clear of those movies' bull-♥♥♥♥, and should not be considered when deciding whether or not to purchase and play this game.

Overview STAR WARS Republic Commando is, at the time of this review, over 11 years old. I remember playing this game a couple years after it came out, back on my original XBOX. I was just a little kid back then. If you are buying this game now, it's almost certainly for nostalgia, as it most definitely was for me. In this review I'll go over how the graphics/performance, gameplay, and plot hold up over a decade later, and some closing thoughts.

Graphics/Performance While I have heard some complaints of Commando not working on peoples modern rigs, I am running a PC on Windows 10 with no components older than 2012, and I ran this game just fine. I cranked up all the graphical settings, except turning on FSAA as that would cause my game to crash almost immediately. The max resolution of Commando is 1024x768, but you can change it to any res as long as you are willing to tweak one of the games system files. It absolutely makes the game look much sharper, but I found that the game was extremely choppy in 1080p, despite getting 100+ fps, so I stuck with 1024x768. Now on with the overall looks. They are ugly. I really doubt anyone who didn't play this game a long time ago will be able to stomach the graphics because of how spoiled we are today. For me they were definitely an eye sore, but I put up with it because it was hard to criticize something I remember from my childhood. All in all, the visuals and performance are just barely passable as long as you can put up with them for old times’ sake.

Gameplay The gameplay of Commando was very varied for its time, but not all that much by today’s standards. You'll find yourself fighting lots of the same enemies, in very tedious battles. You'll have your squad members to back you up and give commands to, but even what they can do for you gets very old and repetitive. Small arms, heavy arms, melee, grenades, turrets, and explosive charges, these are your tools for fighting the onslaught of various droids, Geonosians, Trandoshans, and the odd battleship. It can be tense and tough at times, but can also feel very samey and drawn out. Once again though, the saving grace was my recollection of scenes and actions I had almost completely forgotten, which made the monotonous gameplay with the rare tense moment more than just sufferable.

Plot You are Delta 38, commissioned with your squad members 07 (Sev), 40 (Fixer), and 62 (Scorch) to be a covert and elite clone task force, whose job is to strike swiftly and hard at the republic's foes. You have been born and bred to work together as a team, and are much more skilled than your lowly infantry-ranked cousins. STAR WARS Republic Commando will take you through 3 primary locations (littered with objectives for you and your squad), where you will blast your way through copious enemies. From Geonosis to a republic star ship, and finally the Wookie home planet of Kashyyyk, the experience really is bad ♥♥♥. Especially so when I think of 5-6 year old me making my way through it. There it is again, the nostalgia factor. Very important for playing this game in 2016, onwards.

Final Thoughts Republic Commando is an 8-9 hour long linear Star Wars tactical-shooter I'd only recommend you play if you have some deep nostalgia for it, or if you are a total Star Wars fanatic. In my case (as you've probably caught on) it was the nostalgia. However, I did find that part of the magic 5 or 6 year old me preserved up to teenage me was misleading, and some of my love for this game has now been worn away. But that's beside the point now, so I'll just rephrase the theme of this review to end it off. I'd suggest anyone with memories of this game in their childhood to take another swing at it, otherwise, steer clear. I'm living proof nostalgia was enough to make this game worth reliving.

Personal Rating: 8/10

reviewText: I know I'm a bit late to the party on this one since the game was released almost 11 years ago as of this review, but this game is actually pretty good for what is. The game is fairly challenging, the AI honestly isn't half-bad, and the overall gameplay is pretty damn good; the music is great, the voice acting is solid, and the game actually looks pretty good for its time. My only real gripes are that the game feels a bit short for the campaign (personal opinion, I just felt that it was a bit shorter than what I expected) and that the ending feels like a bit of a cop-out since it leaves the player feeling as if there's going to be a sequel (which we all know is unfortunately never happening). I'd definitely say something about the multiplayer as well if I could, but since the multiplayer has been rendered non-functional due to GameSpy's shutdown, I'm unfortunately not able to do so.\n\nIn the end, I'd definitely say that this is a game I'd recommend, even without the multiplayer being functional.

reviewText:
Star Wars Republic Commando is a unique experience for a Star Wars game. You don't play as a Jedi or a Bounty Hunter or any of the things in between. Instead you get plopped directly into the head of a Clone trooper and thrown onto the battlefields of Episode Two.

As a clone trooper you don't get much back story or indeed any motivation beyond the occasional communication pop-up on your UI that tells you where to go next. Indeed you were bred for combat and unquestioning loyalty and that's what you do. This rather unique aspect does a lot of alleviate many of the problems that usually plague Star Wars games and makes Republic Commando a rather enjoyable experience.

You are not just any Clone Trooper however, you are a squad leader and this is where the gameplay of Republic Commando comes into play. With you have 3 additional commandos, each with their own area of expertise. A sniper, a demolitions expert and a hacker. As you go through the missions you will be able to order your team around, into cover, mounting gun positions, or performing specific tasks suited to their specialty through a context sensitive command system. You basically just point at an object and click and one of your squad members takes the appropriate action. This all works surprisingly well and trying to play the game as a lone wolf tends to end badly as the game features some rather impressive AI, both on the part of your teammates and the enemies.

The game is very pretty and in particular the background deserves notice as there is always something else going on there which often looks every bit as intense as the fight you are distracted from.

The voice-acting is pretty good for a game but you will quickly realize that the developers took a little shortcut here as the many different voices and accents the clones have makes you wonder just how similar they really are.

Star Wars Republic Commando is an attempt to take the Star Wars franchise into the squad based tactical genre and it comes away from the attempt quite nicely although it is a game that has it's flaws, most notably the campaign is extremely short and ends with a cliffhanger that's never resolved as this is the only game in the franchise. Still all in all it's one of the best Star Wars games out there and one of those that can be held up as a good game in it's own right.

reviewText: As a Star Wars fan, this was fun.  It's a first person shooter, has nothing to do with the elite characters of the movie, instead you are a clone trooper.  The teamwork works great, at least they listen to what you want them to do.  Outside of that, the AI isn't great for either your partners or for the enemies.  There are a variety of enemies, some that are rather tough, and others that just annoy.  The weapons are decent, but nothing spectacularly new.  The storyline is intriguing and connects somewhat well within the Star Wars Universe.  The fun, didn't last through the entire game though as the game gets quite repetitive.  The graphics aren't too interesting to look at these days, and this isn't to say that they aren't good, just that there's no real art design that stands out.  Everything seems bleak and without much detail.\n\nIf you are not a Star Wars fan, this may not tickle your fancy.  However, it's a short game that can easily be beaten in less than 10 hours.  I enjoyed it.

reviewText:
It's not very often a Star Wars game (specifically this one) goes on sale. I remember playing this a few years ago when it first came out, just picked it up on Steam, too. Had loads of fun playing the campaign, lots of great memories from this game. I remember hugging the healing stations because I was worried I'd get killed during the next fight all the time.

You can play as different specialized Clone Troopers (i.e. Demolitions, Sniper, etc.).

This is actually one of those games where commanding your own squad is fun. The AI is decent (not perfect, but close enough). You can use turrets from fallen Republic Gunships and mow down enemies with it. All in all, a great game.. multiplayer wasn't that bad too. I had lots of fun dueling 1v1. One day, I was lucky enough to pull a direct headshot by bouncing a Wookie crossbow projectile off the wall on somebody. :D: Been a while, and I can't remember the name of the map, but it was an arena map called Clone Training".

I give the game a 8.5/10. Although the game was pretty enjoyable

reviewText:
Star Wars, Republic Commando  Note: I have never played multiplayer, (as it was shut down with the exception of GameRanger servers) so I will not be covering it.

Star Wars, Republic Commando is a brilliant game. You play as the leader of Delta Squad; an elite squad of four clone commandos, each with their own respective ability (Sniper, Slicer/hacker, etc.) however from memory, it doesn't entire matter whom you order to do what.
Stats Republic Commando Contains:
Three different campaign missions, each lasting several hours
A total campaign length of around 10 hours at a moderate pace
Very different atmospheres within the respective missions
A canon addition to the Star Wars story line (I believe Disney kept it as canon) Pros Older game, therefore built to be run on toasters
One of very few genuinely good Star Wars games
With squad commands, you can order AI to target specific enemies, or preform certain tasks, allowing you to concentrate on a primary objective.
A good plot, that gives you another perspective of the clone wars Cons Bad graphics, but the game IS old
At points, there is some repetition, but the concepts that are repeated are quite good, and do not easily get old
While sometimes the game is so hard one will likely have to temporarily lower the difficulty, other times, it is ridiculously easy, and players will not find any challenge in these moments.
Overall Rating  8/10

reviewText:
This game is so good that i had to buy it again after i lost my original version of the game.

Pros:
~Amazing action-packed about 8h story
~Phenominal voice acting and backround music
~Flawless combat

Cons:
~Ocational glitches/bugs for example a team mate goes down but cant be revived
~The AI can sometimes be a little dumb but nothing too major
~For me atleast the story was a bit too short

Conclusion:
I would give this game 9/10. Its pretty much a must-buy for any Star Wars fan.

reviewText:
Equal parts tactical strategy game and first-person shooter, Republic Commando proves itself greater than the sum of its parts.  Enemy encounters are varied and fun, in a way that only sci-fi shooters can be with their assortment of alien and robotic adversaries.  Squad commands are doled out in a system that is about as intuitive as possible, at least until voice recognition works its way into the realm of gaming.  On top of it all, great writing that de-emphasizes the Jedi Order does something that George Lucas failed to do; it makes the prequels cool.

Republic Commando is the rare Star Wars game that is more than just a money grab, and you know it because it would be just as good without all of the licensing.

For a full review, check out:
http://amanandhismouse.com/republic-commando.html

reviewText:
A Star Wars game without any Jedi around, instead focusing on squad-based battles and tactical combat solving. As an FPS it takes inspiration from all the right sources, including Metroid Prime for its famous HUD.

Pros
* Tacticool as ♥♥♥♥. Door breaching, landmine ambush, air support, everything is there
* Good ability at creating a believable atmosphere with a mix of large battles and claustrophobic resistance
* Excellent OST, with some very bad asses Mandalorian songs

Cons
* Low variety of weapons and enemies
* You're never given quite enough ammunition to kill armored droids

Note that the ending is a slightly-frustrating cliffhanger that will likely never be resolved. Make sure to properly order your squaddies around for you won't go far without being a good field officer.

reviewText:
Here's my bottom line opinion on Republic Commando; it's the second-best Star Wars first-person shooter. Just below Dark Forces. It has the unfortunate distinction of being the best game to come out of the prequel trilogy, and doesn't escape the taint of the prequel's legacy. I may even like the ideas behind Republic Commando more than I like the game itself.

Here is what sucks about Republic Commando: the weapons sound weak, and there aren't many different enemies to fight. So what does Republic Commando do right? The intro to the game is great. It details where you and your squad came from, all from the first person perspective. In fact, this game takes a page from Half-Life in that the entire game is played from the first-person perspective. There are a couple of scenes where you are not in control of your character, but they're limited.

The squad AI is not smart but it's competent. They'll kill enemies, heal themselves, heal you when you drop, take cover, etc. There are certain set pieces that you can order a squadmate to take position at for a specific purpose (like sniping or anti-armor) and they're meant to be used. Your squad dies less when they're in one of these ordered positions. The squad also has fantastic vocal banter. Each member is a personality, and I got attached to them as the game went along.

Though the levels are a little cookie cutter, there are plenty of objectives to them and no lack for fights. I was fighting in corridors, in small courtyards and hangers, on multi-level starship bridges, and in trees. They're not as varied as Dark Forces, but each environment is well made.

And now I can get to what stops this from being a great game. They can fix the sound effects and toss in a couple more enemies, but it's harder to change the setting. Republic Commando takes place at the onset of the Clone Wars. It starts on Geonosha even. And though it takes place over a two (three?) year span, it could have gone farther. This was a pre-Episode 3 game and it shows. It feels like a teaser leading up to Episode 3 and, ultimately, suffers for that. It doesn't deserve to be timely movie release fodder. It deserves to be treated like a game that can stand on its own two legs. Something that can be taken out of the context of the prequel release. It doesn't deserve to be lumped in with Episode 1 Racer, Star Wars Starfighter, Bounty Hunter, Obi-Wan, or any other godawful prequel game.

It doesn't carry the same tone as those games. The developers did their damnedest to give this game a fair chance. They go out of their way to make  you know that you are playing an elite soldier. You're no jedi, and you're not fodder either. You see your share of ally deaths and the Clone War takes its toll. But you're fighting bugs on Geonosha. And battle droids, even if they're way more menacing than they ever were in the prequel movies. They may bleed oil, wear a metallic gray paint job (rather than the orange seen in the movies), and the super battle droids may be some tough ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, but they're still battle droids, which are inherently lame. There's a pitiful tie in with General Grieveous in the form of his bodyguards, which flip and hop around like acrobats, with electric sticks. They're not threatening in the slightest, more annoying than anything, and serve only to give General Grieveous an excuse to make an unwarranted appearance.

What I'm getting down to is that in Republic Commando you are playing, in essence, a proto super stormtrooper. I wish the devs would've been allowed to run with that rather than get tied to the time frame that stuck them between the two prequel movies. I hope we can get another Republic Commando game, but I'm not expecting it. This franchise has legs that get cut out from beneath it by the movies it was made to support.

reviewText:
If you've played it before and have $10 to spare or if it's on sale, absolutely get it. The community for it mostly gone but if you REALLY want to get some multiplayer action going, there are small groups like ReiGn that will play and have servers up. I may or may not get one myself. There are plenty of mods for the game as well. I haven't put that much time looking into it but I believe there is one that adds an entire new campaign.

Never played it before? This game is within that top tier of all Star Wars games ever made. Amazing and unique gameplay + story. The chat between your squad as you progress makes it even better. It can be incredibly challenging even now if you turn the diff. all the way up. The squad mechanic also ups the difficiutly a bit as you will need to utilize them correctly if you want to get anywhere.  You are not a God (i.e a Jedi) in this game and it will remind you if you try to lone wolf it.

Like I said the game still looks AMAZING considering how old it is. One thing that makes this stand out in my eyes is that like the story for BF2, this is one is told from the Clone perspetive rather than the overdone Jedi one. All in all yes get this game. Maybe with all the hype coming back to Star Wars with the new movie and BF3 we'll finally get a sequel.

reviewText:
This has to be one of my favorite games of all time. Not because it is Star Wars or anything like that. Partly cause it is Star Wars actually. But it has a certain feel to it that other games don't give me. Especially FPS wise.
FPS wise I mainly stick with Halo cause I really enjoy Sci-Fi. For awhile Halo was my go to FPS. But this game takes that position now. Yes, I could be fighting the flood and watching them devour people. But for some reason that never made me as nervous as when I was roaming the abandoned Republic ship as Clones got torn limb from limb in the room next to me. Yes, I could be trying to take down a hunters. But a lot of villains in this game provide much more of a challenge.

Another aspect of the game is the squad. You control your squad and tell them where to go. I'm constantly checking my squad's health and changing their positions. Yes, some current games have squads. You kinda control them, but I don't think as much as in this game. But that's just my opinion.

With a compelling story and constant threats trying to kill you, this game makes for a great experience.

I feel that the weapon feel underpowered and I had difficulty at first.  But slowly I learn to rely on the squad members more, commanding them take sniping/grenade position, it became less overwheming.

I am only over one-fifth of the game and I like what I have played so far.  You don't need to be Star Wars fan to enjoy (I am not).

reviewText: This is one of the most criminally-underrated shooters ever made. The game manages to fully immerse the player in the Star Wars universe without using Jedi, force powers, or any other hallmarks typical of the Star Wars franchise. This is a tactical first-person shooter played from the perspective of a Clone Trooper, one of the expendable mooks" who drop like flies in the movies and are predecessors to the Stormtroopers
date: the ultimate "disposable bad guy." Each member of the squad is a clone
recommended: but they behave with distinctive personalities and voices that make you actually care about them.\n\nThe game has a fairly good difficulty curve
hoursPlayed: with the game gradually spacing bacta tanks and ammo dumps farther and farther apart as the game progresses without becoming noticeable. You will need to use teamwork to knock out larger enemies like spider droids
voteText: which are almost impossible to down with the limited grenade launcher ammo you have. To drive the importance of team work home
helpfulPercent: the game has several sections where the squad splits
votesHelpful: meaning you have no one to revive you if you die. And you have at most 6 hits on normal difficulty before you're a goner.\n\nThe presentation is fantastic. The graphics have aged well and it runs smoothly on modern operating systems with no compatibility issues. The soundtrack is a masterpiece
votesTotal: with memorable pieces like the Mandalorian chant "Vode An" punctuating intense action sequences
votesFunny: as well as familiar snippets from the film scores. The game will throw in bits of fan-service such as a squad mate quipping "these must be the droids we're looking for" which just make you chuckle even under pressure.\n\nThe AI is decent but will occasionally get stuck behind barriers when rushing to revive you
commentsCount: leading to frustration. The cooperative nature of the campaign makes the lack of online co-op campaign play very glaring. If this game ever gets a sequel
column16: this feature needs to be added first. The campaign only features three planets
column17: and is pretty short. None of the multiplayer maps are very interesting. These are probably due to the game's status as a tie-in for Episode III's film release with crunched development time.\n\nJust get this game. You will not be disappointed. It's not perfect by any means but its extremely minor flaws do little to hamper an amazing experience. For a 9-year-old game it's extremely playable and not dated at all."

reviewText:
Despite me not having many hours on here. I put countless hours on this years ago back on my original Xbox. This game (in my opinion) still holds up with modern day games. Unfortunately, there are few and far between squad-based games out there like this. The only ones that still carry on this tradition would be Rainbow Six and Ghost Recon for example (Singleplayer at least). Which we need more games like this, instead of these one man superpowered (yet normal) soldiers that can regenerate wounds after getting shot multiple times, and with unintelligent A.I. (that seem like that they're just for show, like a hindrance, rather than helping the player take care of hostiles) that stays back 10 feet behind while the player is on the other side of the map, blasting their way through enemy territory.

We need less games like that, and more of this, if the FPS Genre wants to at least survive in someway. Definitely worth buying, that is, if you like to work as a team. If you can't handle that responsibility, then look somewhere else.

Oh and this game actually has a challenge to it. Pretty rare nowadays in the FPS Genre.

9.7/10 Would buy and play again.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Like a swift kick to the stomach, this game will leave you doubled-over and gasping for breath hours after you finish playing. How many times have I been forced to kill a spider droid on my own with just a pistol because I ran out of ammo and my entire squad is incapacitated, or how often have I encountered a droid dispenser pumping out SBD's only to realize I've already used up all my anti-armor charges? These kinds of situations force to think ahead and plan & execute your strategies quickly. Keeping your squad organized is key. It's a beatiful thing when you give your squadmates commands and then find out that what you've decided for them to do is the perfect strategy. Good ol' Delta 38... he always knows just what to do.

Squad control in the game is easy as pie, and the friendly AI is okay, though at times a bit frustrating. When they're given a command, the squad will go do it no matter what, even if it means doing something dumb like getting killed because they don't think to kill the things in their way first. Enemies are pretty stupid, but you don't need to be smart when you're a Super Battle Droid. The graphics and landscapes are dated but still amazing, from the windy, dusty canyons of Geonosis to the dark and foreboding forests of Kashyyyk. Except for the commando armor, everything is dark and gloomy. Gameplay is also awesome; everything is fast-paced and keeps you on the edge of your seat (and sometimes out of it completely). Whether you're desperately trying to hold off an endless stream of enemies as one of your squadmates plants explosives on a droid dispenser while another hacks into a security system while under fire, or you're clearing a path through a group of fat Trandoshan slavers in the maze-like corridors of an assault ship, there's never a dull moment in Republic Commando, and the hard difficulty mode is just right.

The Squad:

Delta 38, the main character. A tough-as-nails commando, 38 don't take no crap from nobody. Even when under heavy fire, he calmly gives commands like he's ordering food at a McDonald's drive-thru. He's the voice of reason, keeping everybody under control.

Delta 62 (Scorch), the Demolitions expert. Scorch likes explosives. That's all there is to say.

Delta 07 (Sev), is a fierce hunter. His best use is as a sniper, providing amazingly accurate covering fire for his squadmates. His only job is to kill, kill, kill.

Delta 40 (Fixer), is just a good old-fashioned soldier. He's uncomplicated and a great fighter, and always follows orders. Other than that, I'm not quite sure what his deal is... I guess he's the computer expert
date:
though any commando can slice any console.

Each commando has his own personality. Scorch can be quite humorous at times, and Sev has some pretty disturbing things to say. One thing I don't understand is why do all have different voices? I though they were all the same clones...

Trust me when I saw that even still to this day this game is worth every penny. The only thing I wish is that more games could be like this.

reviewText: CONS: Guns aim poorly with tiny bullets, do absolutely ♥♥♥♥ poor damage & some of the enemies take forever to kill, even on easy. The somewhat decent guns that kill large enemies take *FOREVER* to reload and ammo is laughably sparse through out the entire game.  The large enemies are way too common to be anything special.  Holding down the use key to slice terminals and blow up walls can be tiresome, even when you have your allies do it for you.  Your allies are frail little water balloons that you have to constantly revive and have them revive you, so its extremely frustrating.  There is hardly any enemy variety.  PROS: The storyline is interesting, the voice acting is quite good (though the advisor has a weird accent), and it is after all, Star Wars.  This game is hard to recommend so you better like Star Wars & FPS.\n\nTL;DR: If you like FPS & Star Wars and are willing to put up with a lot of problems and frustrating BS, this is worth $1, $2 at most.

reviewText:
This game came out in 2005 and has a much better squad system then halo: reach which came out in 2010.

You play as Delta 38 aka Boss, leader of an elite clone commando squad. You lead your squad of 4 commandos across 3 different campaigns during the era of the clone wars. Each campaign is relatively short (around 2 hours) but feel unique enough to give you a different experience through each one. Atmosphere is great and so is the soundtrack.

Using your squad effectively is very important to succeed in this game. You can't finish this game by yourself you need to use your AI controled squad. Your squad consists of 3 other commandos that all have different strengths and personalities, which leads to some good interactions and interesting dialogue. The squad commanding is very simple but also one of the most effective ways i've ever seen in any game, even in 2016.

the game ends on a cliffhanger ending, originally planned to continue the story in a sequel. unfortunatly this game got scrapped so the game ends with a very important part of the story unexplained.

Rating 8.5/10.

reviewText: This is one of the most criminally-underrated shooters ever made. The game manages to fully immerse the player in the Star Wars universe without using Jedi, force powers, or any other hallmarks typical of the Star Wars franchise. This is a tactical first-person shooter played from the perspective of a Clone Trooper, one of the expendable mooks" who drop like flies in the movies and are predecessors to the Stormtroopers
date: the ultimate "disposable bad guy." Each member of the squad is a clone
recommended: but they behave with distinctive personalities and voices that make you actually care about them.\n\nThe game has a fairly good difficulty curve
hoursPlayed: with the game gradually spacing bacta tanks and ammo dumps farther and farther apart as the game progresses without becoming noticeable. You will need to use teamwork to knock out larger enemies like spider droids
voteText: which are almost impossible to down with the limited grenade launcher ammo you have. To drive the importance of team work home
helpfulPercent: the game has several sections where the squad splits
votesHelpful: meaning you have no one to revive you if you die. And you have at most 6 hits on normal difficulty before you're a goner.\n\nThe presentation is fantastic. The graphics have aged well and it runs smoothly on modern operating systems with no compatibility issues. The soundtrack is a masterpiece
votesTotal: with memorable pieces like the Mandalorian chant "Vode An" punctuating intense action sequences
votesFunny: as well as familiar snippets from the film scores. The game will throw in bits of fan-service such as a squad mate quipping "these must be the droids we're looking for" which just make you chuckle even under pressure.\n\nThe AI is decent but will occasionally get stuck behind barriers when rushing to revive you
commentsCount: leading to frustration. The cooperative nature of the campaign makes the lack of online co-op campaign play very glaring. If this game ever gets a sequel
column16: this feature needs to be added first. The campaign only features three planets
column17: and is pretty short. None of the multiplayer maps are very interesting. These are probably due to the game's status as a tie-in for Episode III's film release with crunched development time.\n\nJust get this game. You will not be disappointed. It's not perfect by any means but its extremely minor flaws do little to hamper an amazing experience. For a 9-year-old game it's extremely playable and not dated at all."

reviewText: Republic Commando is a nice squad based first person shooter. Playing as a clone delta squad commander provides a fresh perspective in the Star Wars universe where you get to use a blaster instead of a light saber. The squad based system is simple and easy to use and the AI actually follows orders well. The small assortment of weapons and attachments isn't impressive, but they get the job done. The game offers an engaging tactical story and traditional Star Wars music. There's no in-game options for wide screen resolution support, but you can manually modify some .ini files to get higher resolutions working. And the graphics look decent at 1920x1080.\n\nAlthough there's nothing great about it, Republic Commando is definitely a polished game that is fun from start to finish--worthy of its 2005 release date.

reviewText:
This game was a bit of Fun. I'll just say this: It is old, but it is fun. To be fair, i haven't touched the multiplayer. I Gather it doesn't work without 3rd party servers but I'm not to sure so i'm reviewing this on the single player.

Pro's:
1) Star wars game! usually they are pretty good and this was deinetally one of them. If you enjoy Star Wars games, play this.

2) The music is honorable to the movies. It was nice to be running around with battle music from star wars going in the background, it really supported the feel of the game.

3) It's a different take on the general star wars universe. Your not a Jedi (Pro and Con) which is fun for a change in the Star Wars Games.

4) Wookies!!!

5) The allies in your party are not full ♥♥♥♥♥♥. They actually do damage. You can also tell them to slice, blow up doors e.t.c and although primitive it still works and add's to the gamplay.

Con's:

1) The AI for the enemy is just...can't say anymore than that.

2) It's an older game. There are some moments were you can tell it's aged badly.

**NOTE THIS ONE IS A SPOILER**
3) The storyline. It's nothing fantastic but i feel that it could of been a little bit better. I like that it's set during the clone war era, i like running around as an elite team, i don't like how the storyline is practically inexistant. And that ending! What kind of ending is that.

4) It is far from a long game. The whole game took me about 5.5 hours to complete.

Overall, the game is enjoyable and i definetally suggest it for a star wars fan. 7/10

reviewText: This game is worth every cent that I payed and possibly even more if the story was longer! (already a fairly long and fun story, don't worry). I played this game non-stop on the hardest difficulty as soon as I got it and it is honestly perfect in every way. This game, not even kidding in any way, has thebest beginning to any game I've played. The awe that I felt as I saw my character's life begin was simply wonderful and irreplacable, it might just be me but everything about this was just beautiful and unforgettable. Enough of that though (I love this game so f**king much) it's time to go on to your squad. The squad gameplay is amazing and unlike most squad features in most triple A title games nowadays. The basics of what I'm saying are that there's good control over your squad and that without you your squad will likely die and if you're alone you will likey die, only together can you effectively triumph against you enemies both weak and strong. The story itself is fun and effectively gave me a feeling of bonding and love with my team, all of them of distinct personalities and traits that make them unique and lovable, they will even occasionally crack a joke between one another or yell something that makes me laugh or smile. To be completely honest, with how amazing this game is I am very suprised that it isn't as loved or known as star wars battlefront is. I'd much prefer this game over that (despite battlefront being my chidhood and being simply a great game). I really hope that someone eventually comes to finish the series with its canceled sequel otherwise I shall continue to cry at the thought of what could've been.\n\nas a final verdict I rate this work of art a 10/10, it has no real failings other than age and at this point I honestly want to play it all over again. (I don't usually give games this good of ratings, only other game to get that high on my list is portal 2). I cannot reccomend this game more if you like squad gameplay and fps games or if you like murderous-deep voiced badasses, funny-somewhat timid, or that one guy who follows orders and is fairly serious about most subjects because that's what this squad consists of and I love tham all.

reviewText:
If you're looking into this game, you should really get it.
It's a fantastic game, it has a pretty good story, unique weapons, and you play with your squad for most of the game.
The biggest part of the game is your squad. They're really amazing, you've scorch, sev, and fixer. They all have their specialties, and it's not super noticeable, but they do better than the others in their area. (Scorch- demolitions, fixer-computers/slicing, sev- weapons expert{sniping, anti-armor posts, turrets, etc.}) They listen to your orders, you can set them to do different things. You can have one guy sniping, one guy disabling the droid dispenser and still have the last one fighting head on with you. You can have them on the full offensive, you can have them staying in formation, you can have them moving carefully, ready to blow ammo into anything that moves.

Plus there's the Humour. Really there's some funny jokes in there. Gotta love scorch XD

There's a really unique weapon setup in the game, you can have 3 guns. There's your standardized pistol (infinite ammo, energy recharge), the standardized rifle (with sniping and explosives attachments), and then you can have a single enemy weapon. That could be anything an enemy drops, like a geonosian beam rifle (pretty much shoots a powerful beam of energy) or a trandoshan shotgun, or even a wookie bowcaster. There's also heavy weapons you can get, like the ACP Heavy Repeater or the Wookie Rocket Launcher. Personally, by the end of the game I really only used the pistol, and the rifle attachments if I really need to.

It also has a fair ammount of extra fun one time kind of stuff. Most of them come as a surprise, so I don't really wanna spoil it for you.

When you play, keep in mind how useful cover can really be. You have an energy shield, which recharges, and a pistol with infinite ammo. If you can find some good cover, you can use those two together and take out just about anything with relative ease.

reviewText: After the Jedi Knight/Dark Forces series started focusing more on Lightsaber battles and Force powers (which was eventually expanded even further in the Force Unleashed games) it was refreshing to play a good ol'-fashioned, Star Wars shooter again. The use of Star Wars assets isn't exactly done with the most accurate attention to detail, as the design of the droids and other baddies look very little like their saga counterparts, and the weapons would look very out of place in Lucas' universe, but the gameplay and level design more than make up for it. This is a short-but-sweet, fun, squad-based shooter, which doesn't try to be too clever or reinvent the wheel.\n\nIt's incredible there was never a follow-up, considering the success of the game and the subsequent success of the Clone Wars TV series (which even featured a cameo by the Republic Commando squad), but who knows, maybe one day...

reviewText:
Back in 2005, Star Wars: Republic Commando was an unsung gaming classic, since then it has aged incredibly well in the gameplay department, standing defiant against both the tides of time and the trends of cover-based shooting and regenerating health. The gameplay, weapons, squad mechanics and even the graphics are still appealing even after all this time. The Steam release of Republic Commando is the third time I have bought this game, and I still love to play it now and again.

The first thing that LucasArts got right with this game is making the Commados feel just as bad-♥♥♥ as the Jedi, while at the same time making them feel like soldiers. This is accomplished simply with the squad commands and context-dependant actions such as sniping and grenade positions. The scripted animations are icing on the cake like tackling droidekas or killing a kamikazi trandoshan with his own knives.

But while each member of Delta Squad is comprehensively a one-man killing machine, they are not as invincible as a Jedi Knight, you need your squad, and again this really enhances the military feel of the game. Performing door breaches, setting up entrenched positions, and setting up covering fire while you outflank the enemy do a great deal to give Republic Commando a military feel that few modern military shooters can match. Putting you in command of Delta Squad was an awesome idea.

Atmosphere is another area where this game shines. You start out being dropped behing enemy lines onto Geonosis, fighting your way into a Geonosian hive complex, down through a droid foundry and into a trade federation droid control ship. Then comes the genuinely creepy ghost-ship mission where you will be reduced to being hunted, alone by scavenger droids, and finally you will form part of the first wave in the republic's campaign on Kashyyyk, each location feels unique, and the game manages to capture the frenetic pace of a battlefield, the isolation and helplessness of a horror game, and the epic scale of a megaflora jungle.

While some games start to feel dated and klunky as technology and design practices roll on, Republic Commando was at least 10 years ahead of its time. Everything about it shines, and the few flaws are minor and easily overlooked. Even when it's not on sale, this game is a bargain at ten bucks, the only negative point I can hold against Republic Commando is that it wasn't long enough and never had a sequel.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a very good Star Wars game, made back in the waning days when Lucasarts still cared about video games. You take control of a squad of republic clone troopers each with his own personality (my personal fave is Sev, the cold, silent, deadly sniper on a hunt for blood). The gameplay is short, unfortunately; I think the 14 hours for my playthrough that is listed here is because I either didn't know where to go many times or my file got lost and I had to start over for some reason. At any rate, this game is a must for any hardcore Star Wars fan and perhaps even people who don't care so much about Star Wars and just want some military squad-based action in a science-fiction setting.

Gameplay-wise, this game is terrific. You fight your way through jungles, heavily-fortified enemy bases, desert-terrain, etc as you carry out your missions. You can choose, in many situations, to go head-on with the enemies or sic your bloodthirsty comrades on them with the press of a button.

The music and sounds are top-notch as usual in Star Wars games. You will hear the familar firing of laser blasters and roaring of wookies, not to mention the authentic Star Wars music we all know and love from the movies.

Cons: Game is short, but by today's standards of 8-10 hours, I would say it fits in nicely. Perhaps the AI is a bit boring with the repeated use of hide behind rock

reviewText:
This game is amazing, It's has maybe textures of a game from 2005, but who cares.
You play as a Clone Commander in the republic war and you have a squad of 3 other people.
You don't simply walk around and shoot alien's and people, Like the: Follow-The-Objective and that's it like you would in MW2-3 or anything. but this make's you the bos of your squad, you can command them to go cover you/blow thing's up/hack consoles/snipe people down/stand clear/to follow you or to stay and more.
and if you dislike commanding you squad to do it, you can also do it yourself.

this game has basically a great story, somewhat funny dialoges, good gameplay, and amazing location's to go for mission, maybe it doesn't has a viarity of diffrent location's, but every map is a tough challange that you will enjoy playing.
i played this game when i was a child, and even now i'm playing it. i reccomend this to every star war's lover or even if you just started liking Star Wars a bit.
The sad part is this game is not so popular, but this game is damned amazing.

1000/10
Would keep this game for the rest of my life.

reviewText:
Honestly this is one of the best games I've bought in a long time.
Despite being an old game I've only had it crash once and have encountered no glitches or bugs so far.
It's hard to describe but the game feels right; you're not an all powerful being, you're a clone and you can killed easily by just about any enemy; similarly your weapons pack an equal punch.
It's just so hard to describe, but the one phrase I come back to every time is: it feels right.
The game is worth the money and time: if you want a Clone game then this is the game.

reviewText: After the Jedi Knight/Dark Forces series started focusing more on Lightsaber battles and Force powers (which was eventually expanded even further in the Force Unleashed games) it was refreshing to play a good ol'-fashioned, Star Wars shooter again. The use of Star Wars assets isn't exactly done with the most accurate attention to detail, as the design of the droids and other baddies look very little like their saga counterparts, and the weapons would look very out of place in Lucas' universe, but the gameplay and level design more than make up for it. This is a short-but-sweet, fun, squad-based shooter, which doesn't try to be too clever or reinvent the wheel.\n\nIt's incredible there was never a follow-up, considering the success of the game and the subsequent success of the Clone Wars TV series (which even featured a cameo by the Republic Commando squad), but who knows, maybe one day...

reviewText:
Star Wars: Republic Commando is quite possibly the most fun game I have ever played...no exaggeration.

Republic Commando is a FPS that was released back in 2005 but stills holds up today as an extremely fun game. In the game, you play as RC-1138, AKA 'Boss', who is the...well...BOSS of an elite clone commando squad known as Delta Squad. You have 3 squadmates: Scorch, the munitions expert, Fixer, the computer slicer, and Sev, the sniper. The 4 of you go on many, many missions across the galaxy and basically destroy everyone in your path.

The mechanics of the game are surprisingly smooth and it's easy to get the hang of. You know how to aim at things? You're all good. This game is so worth it for the price not only because of how fun it is, but because of the length of the campaign. I think we've all bought a game and had fun with it but were left short-handed because of how small the campaign was. No worrying about that with this game. You get a blaster rifle, a sniper, shotgun, pistol, grenades, and even a grenade launcher to blow your enemies to hell all while your squad mates are bantering with each other...which is probably one of the best parts of the game.

TL;DR Here is a pros and cons list

PROS
-Good amount of content
-Smooth mechanics
-Squad banter
-Good graphics for its release date
-No extra BS. You shoot things.

CONS
-There isn't a sequel.......YET.

(I don't have much play time on Steam at all because I mostly played it on my CD version.)
