reviewText:
This is an amazing game, and probably my favourite FPS.
It's also very short. There are three mini campaigns, which you play through sequentially. One on Geonosis, one onboard a Republic cruiser and one on Kashyyyk, all of them clock in at around 2 hours each.

With that big, primary concern out of the way, do I recommend this game? I sure do.
Beyond nailing the aesthetic of the Clone Wars (more the one from the films than the tv series) or even Star Wars in general it is a solid single player squad based shooter.
Single player and squad based might sound like opposing descriptors, but they're not. The three titular Commandos are your greatest weapon, both in effectiveness and enjoyment. Every Commando can do what you do, at the same rate.
Do you want to dash in behind the enemy battle droids and take out their dispenser or do you want to send one of your squad mates to do it so you can lay down covering fire? You'll have them hack their way into power generators to reactivate them, but could just as well do that yourself.
Should they fall you can revive them by running up to them with a defibrillator, or order one of the remaining squad mates to do that. Even if you get shot down yourself your squad mates will, at your orders, run over and put you back on your feet.

Opposing you are the expected Trade Federation droids, the Geonosian bug army and, the only group not plucked directly from the prequel trilogy, Trandoshan mercenaries. These all have their share of easy fodder (the basic federation droids especially are little more than target practice) as well as a variety of overwhelmingly strong enemies.
If the game did not work as well as it does then the best strategy would be to have your squad hold its ground out of harm's way, go at it alone and have them come revive you if it doesn't work out, and it's a testament to the excellent work the developers put into making the squad mechanics worthwhile.

Orders are given easily, point at a piece of cover and press the Order button to have a squad mate take cover behind it. Same goes with entering turrets, breaching doors, setting explosives, etc. etc..
It's a simple system, but it works well and is easy enough to do in the middle of hectic combat situations, of which there are plenty.
The plot doesn't really add anything to existing lore, but it does its job and all of your squad mates have their own distinctive personalities, voices and preferences (though the explosives expert is no faster at placing a charge than his brothers).

As long as you keep in mind that this is a short game and that it will primarily stay away from the plot of the films then you're in for a great time, and I recommend this title.

reviewText:
Star Wars Republic Commando tells the story of The Clone Wars by the point of view of the leader of a elite commando squad from the Republic fighting against the army of droids and mercenaries of the Separatists. With you there are three other commandos that you give orders in field during each mission,such as slicing door,planting detonators etc.

The graphics are nothing to boost about,they are what 2005 games looked like in the day,but the music is great seeing as it triggers only in the right moments. The gameplay is pretty satisfaying and it really makes this game the best FPS i ever played.

The only thing i didn't like about this game is how it has a range of 8-10 hours of campaign,which is pretty short. Even more if you consider that the game ends abruptly AND with a cliffhanger,with a sequel that may never be made.

reviewText: We NEED more games like this. Squad-based action gave a whole new dimension to FPS. It's hard enough to keep yourself alive, but when you need to look out for 3 other troopers as well, it so much more than a brainless shoot 'em up.  At least give us a redux with modern graphics. reviewText:
A game ahead of its time
Star Wars Rebublic Commando is set in the early stages of the Clone Wars. You are a clone commander in charge of Delta Squad, the republics deadliest soldiers. You and your squad are sent behind enemy lines and must fight the droids of CIS (confederacy of independent systems) However, the droids are not the only threat you must face.

A very clever and simple squad based gameplay

When I first dove into the game, I was expecting a squad based system which would be confusing, similar to Red Orchestra 2. The system was actually pretty simple. It did not take long to learn the mechanics. You have just a few buttons which you can use to give your squad commands. Commands such as defend this area, follow me, advance (search and destroy), cancel orders. You can also order your men to different highlighted positions like, sniper,anti armor, turrets and grenade. Might sound confusing, but it really isn't. I was surprised of the good physics in this game and the gameplay itself was fun, but only for a couple of hours. The maps and basic gameplay got a bit repetitive and I got bored after a half an hour or so each session. Still, it was fun and entertaining.

Short and loose story

the story was not as good as I hoped. You get a short prolouge cutscene that tells you about the clone commandos. The story jumps from one place to the next. At first you are at Geonosis and suddenly you are investigating a lost republic war ship. So it is not a direct storyline throughout the game. What I did like was the chatter between your men. It was funny at many occasions and you got more feelings about your men. It also ends with a cliffhanger and since republic commando 2 was cancelled I doubt that there will be a sequel anytime soon. Though, the developers leaked information about how the story would continue, so the ending is still there.

Worth it?
It was a game ahead of its time, so I can't complain about anything really, except the story. Other than the story being very loose I would still recommend bying it, especially if you are a Star Wars fan. The music is top notch.


Note: Multiplayer does not work anymore, so you will only be able to play singleplayer, still worth it though

reviewText:
Star Wars Republic Commando is a significant deviation from the previous Star Wars games I’ve played (Dark Forces/Jedi Knight) and definitely a more modern take on the franchise. If you thought it was weird how storm/clone troopers fought their enemies in battle lines like Civil War era musket infantry, you’ll appreciate the “special forces” feel of Republic Commando.

The game starts near the end of the second Star Wars prequel movie “Attack of the Clones” where the massive clone army is landing on the Separatist planet Geonosis. While the Jedi Knights and Grand Army of the Republic (clone troopers) are fighting on the surface, a four man group of clone commandos is performing covert actions in the underground Geonosian tunnels and even infiltrating the CIS command ships parked on the ground. You play Delta 38, the leader of Delta Squad, a team of “enhanced” clones who take on special assignments. It’s hinted in the opening animation that even though most clones are genetically identical, the commandos have some sort of physical superiority. You definitely have better firepower.

Republic Commando is a first person shooter with heavy squad based gameplay. With a single contextual “use” button, you issue orders to the other three commandos on your team such as door breach, focus target, hack consoles, etc. You can also order team members to use various fighting positions that appear on your hud. This includes sniping positions, grenade positions, and heavy weapon positions. Your computer controlled team has exactly the same weapons that you have, but most of the time they only use the special weapons when assigned to the special positions in the field. There aren’t that many weapons to choose from actually, but there’s plenty of ammo all over the place. This is good because most of the guns can be ineffective depending on who you’re fighting. If everyone has to die right now though, start throwing your grenades.

Pros:
+A lot of teamwork involved in the single player campaign. In the sections where you’re fighting by yourself you will notice just how much harder the game is without your brothers backing you up. Most importantly, you won’t be revived if you get knocked out, which will happen A LOT.
+The game runs parallel to the movie storylines (though movie characters don’t really show up) so if you’re familiar with the Star Wars prequel movies you’ll have a good idea what’s going on. There are three game campaigns: Geonosis, RAS Prosecutor (a spooky abandoned ship), and Kashyyyk (the Wookie home world). This isn’t Call of Duty where your team is a bunch of people you don’t care about. Your Delta Squad brothers are with you from beginning to end.
+There’s quite a mix up of enemies to fight and usually you have a bunch of different ways to go about clearing a room. The easiest is usually busting out one of your 4 different types of grenades, but the heavy anti-armor gun is always fun too. You don’t get to control any vehicles like in the Battlefront games, but you can man a few different stationary gun turrets (or order your men to do it).

Cons:
-The difficulty of the game seems to vary wildly, especially when dealing with enemies who use melee weapons. Sometimes they just seem to cut you down in one shot. This isn’t a big deal most of the time because your team members can quickly revive you, but during the second campaign, those scavenger droids are a nightmare. I get the feeling they’re just supposed to be an annoyance, but they can absolutely wreck you.
-I mentioned before that the weapons seem weak, but they might just be more suited for fighting certain types of enemies.  Your blaster rifle is decent against the weak droids and Geonosians but seems to be terrible against everything else. There are a few different guns that you can pick up from fallen enemies as well, but with the exception of a couple rare ones, they’re not so hot either. Get used to emptying an entire clip to kill one enemy.
-No co-op multiplayer! A game like this would be amazing if you could go through the game with a team of friends since the computer is already controlling the small team. Unfortunately the multiplayer seems to be restricted to basic PvP.

Overall Republic Commando is probably my favorite Star Wars game (so far). It’s action packed with a strong story and it’s not so old that I’m embarrassed to run it on a modern computer. Definitely give the game a try if you can get your hands on it.

reviewText: Very easily one of my favorite shooters. reviewText:
Product received for free

let me preface this by admitting i got this game as a gift from a friend, but only because i was literally to poor to afford it at sale price. I hadn't bought it before simply because i didn't know much about it and was simply going by word of mouth that it was a good game.

That being said, however, I would definitely pay full price for this game (maybe even $30-$40 for a graphical overhaul version)

this game, alongside other titans of the star wars series such as battlefront I & II (before DICE) is easily ne of the best games of it's time and will be an iconic standout, at least to me. the fact that this game even runs on my machine is a marvel, considering it's not even rated for windows 7 on a good computer and im runing it on a piece of trash with windows 10, another piece of trash. Many other reviews have mentioned bugs and crashing, this is simply because their V-Sync wasn't implemented well and the resolution needs to be changed through console commands to work properly(albeit they souldn't have to deal with these issues, they are not complex and im sure you can figure it out, if not the forums exist). on the topic of addressing complaints: the AI is a bit dated, but we're talking like Call of Duty MW3/BO2 era AI here, so i'm not really seeing and issue for this game. Literally any other game i've played from this era has left me agast at how one-sided ad flat the AI is and how unable it is to interact with the player and adapt to new requests. The only real issues i had with the AI was the occasional oh hey imma switch cover i hope no one is throwing a grenade at my back on the way over."

reviewText: Pay no attention to the year of release, this game holds up remarkably well.  A single player squad based shooter that is also very fast paced is a rare find, and the game play is definitely fun.  You get to issue commands to 3 AI teammates who can hold their own quite well.  The banter is also pretty entertaining to listen to. Also, very rarely will you see your companions do stupid things.  We all know games where ai is more a hindrance then a benefit, and this is not one of those by any means.  You could just ignore squad commands most of the time, but telling a member to hole up in a sniper position will make them very much more effective.\n\nIt's a great game, that just happens to take place in the star wars universe.  Which is a very, very good thing if your a fan. If you are a fan of star wars don't even hesitate as this game is well worth your time.  If you don't care much for the franchise the game play is still very much worth a playthrough.  I highly recommend this game!

reviewText:
NOTE: These are my views of the game, not generally a review, but may help.
What can be said about Star Wars: Republic Commando that hasn't already been said? It's just simply awesome, it may be a game from 2005 but it is a game that is as ageless as it is priceless. My playing hours on this has only recorded a fraction of the time I played as I got it previously a couple of years ago off Steam and played through it and then again offline after I got it here.

I'm a fan of the novels, and this just brings the characters you meet there, namely Delta Squad, to life. 11/10 for sure. Though I speak from a fans perspective, I also say this because the game has great dialogue, iconic characters, and a great amount of action and story that made a mark on the hearts of everyone who played this. A great game.

reviewText:
This is without a doubt one of the best shooters and one of the best Star Wars games to date.

It may be almost 9 years old now, but it is still holding up pretty well. It was that much ahead of its time.

The game's story is not the most epic ever, but it should be enough to keep you interested until the end and it is also one of the more decent stories set in the already exhausted Clone Wars era. The characters are fun and likeable and the dialogue between them is well written.

The game is designed around one multiplayer component and a single player campaign. Personally I have not played multiplayer enough to give an opinion. The campaign is divided in 3 large chapters set in 3 different locales. Each chapter has multiple levels. The campaign is of moderate lenght. An estimate of about 8-10 hours are usually needed to finish it. One downside is that you cannot play the campaign in Co-op, which would have absolutely rocked. But allas, Co-op was not as widespread in 2005 as it is today.

The gameplay is where this game really shines. It is centered around you and your squad and the ability to give order to your squad members. The system is very simple but this makes it easy to use and alows the gameplay to remain relatively fast paced and entertaining. You don't have a wide variety of weapons. But you don't really need more weapons. The main focus of the game is for you to use your squad as a weapon. Speaking of the squad, unlike so many shooters, your squad mates are actually useful. If left to fend for themselves they won't take long to engage threats and defend themselves or take the initiative and revive a fallen squad member. When tasked with something they will do it effectively. The system really works well. The command system combined with the squad AI means that while you will have to micro-manage them in tighter situations, you can still also focus on engaging the enemies yourself. Enemies, like the weapons, don't come in a huge variety but they are enough to keep things interesting until the end. They are also not stupid and different enemies employ different tactics based on their strenghts. You're average separatist droid will act rather inneficient just like in the movies but get swarmed by a couple of them, or pair them with a heavy battle droid and the fight will become much harder.

In terms of sound and graphics the game is doing good even by today's standards. The sound is very well done and with a nice sountrack with both classical Star Wars themes and new ones made specifically for this game. This is a big plus especially since the new tracks are awesome. In terms of graphics, it looked amazing in 2005 but it still looks good today. The good thing is that you can easily edit a .ini file in the game folder to make the gameplay run at whatever resolution you want (1080p included).

All in all this is a game you really should play even if you are just a casual gamer and must play if you consider yourself a hardcore gamer or a Star Wars fan.

reviewText: I remember playing this game when it came out in 2005, and i really liked it then. I recently got it again through steam, and the game is better than i remember it being. In most games where you manage NPCs, they are either unhelpful or impossible to control. This game does not have that problem at all, the rest of your squad is very helpful and would be impossible without them. Also they are very easy to get them to do what you want them to do. I recommend this game to people who like shooters for you can be the biggest factor in completing a mission with your expert aim. I also recommed this game to people who like strategy games because you can miss all of your shots and still beat it on the hardest difficulty. The importance of managing your team is so prevelent that by setting this up right you can win without ever firing a shot. This game has a good balance of the player being able to have a change in the battle, and also not being the key role of a battle. You can change it for good, but the battle won't be lost if you do not meet the skill level"."

reviewText:
This is without a doubt one of the best shooters and one of the best Star Wars games to date.

It may be almost 9 years old now, but it is still holding up pretty well. It was that much ahead of its time.

The game's story is not the most epic ever, but it should be enough to keep you interested until the end and it is also one of the more decent stories set in the already exhausted Clone Wars era. The characters are fun and likeable and the dialogue between them is well written.

The game is designed around one multiplayer component and a single player campaign. Personally I have not played multiplayer enough to give an opinion. The campaign is divided in 3 large chapters set in 3 different locales. Each chapter has multiple levels. The campaign is of moderate lenght. An estimate of about 8-10 hours are usually needed to finish it. One downside is that you cannot play the campaign in Co-op, which would have absolutely rocked. But allas, Co-op was not as widespread in 2005 as it is today.

The gameplay is where this game really shines. It is centered around you and your squad and the ability to give order to your squad members. The system is very simple but this makes it easy to use and alows the gameplay to remain relatively fast paced and entertaining. You don't have a wide variety of weapons. But you don't really need more weapons. The main focus of the game is for you to use your squad as a weapon. Speaking of the squad, unlike so many shooters, your squad mates are actually useful. If left to fend for themselves they won't take long to engage threats and defend themselves or take the initiative and revive a fallen squad member. When tasked with something they will do it effectively. The system really works well. The command system combined with the squad AI means that while you will have to micro-manage them in tighter situations, you can still also focus on engaging the enemies yourself. Enemies, like the weapons, don't come in a huge variety but they are enough to keep things interesting until the end. They are also not stupid and different enemies employ different tactics based on their strenghts. You're average separatist droid will act rather inneficient just like in the movies but get swarmed by a couple of them, or pair them with a heavy battle droid and the fight will become much harder.

In terms of sound and graphics the game is doing good even by today's standards. The sound is very well done and with a nice sountrack with both classical Star Wars themes and new ones made specifically for this game. This is a big plus especially since the new tracks are awesome. In terms of graphics, it looked amazing in 2005 but it still looks good today. The good thing is that you can easily edit a .ini file in the game folder to make the gameplay run at whatever resolution you want (1080p included).

All in all this is a game you really should play even if you are just a casual gamer and must play if you consider yourself a hardcore gamer or a Star Wars fan.

reviewText: I remember playing this game when it came out in 2005, and i really liked it then. I recently got it again through steam, and the game is better than i remember it being. In most games where you manage NPCs, they are either unhelpful or impossible to control. This game does not have that problem at all, the rest of your squad is very helpful and would be impossible without them. Also they are very easy to get them to do what you want them to do. I recommend this game to people who like shooters for you can be the biggest factor in completing a mission with your expert aim. I also recommed this game to people who like strategy games because you can miss all of your shots and still beat it on the hardest difficulty. The importance of managing your team is so prevelent that by setting this up right you can win without ever firing a shot. This game has a good balance of the player being able to have a change in the battle, and also not being the key role of a battle. You can change it for good, but the battle won't be lost if you do not meet the skill level"."

reviewText:
Whenever the best Star Wars are named I have always heard only two. Knights of the Old Rebublic and Battlefront II and while I admit they are very well made games and do somewhat deserve their titles as some of the best the Star Wars series has offered us for some reason Republic Commando went a bit oveshadowed.

Republic Commando in my honest opinion deserve to be called at the very least a great game with solid mechanics and fun gameplay. The characters are memorable to a good degree, I have my favorites but they're all different and have their moments. The shooting is fun and the weapons are varied enough for me to look foward to the next big push my squad and I have to do. The campaign is fairly weak but each mission is a solid and well built section of the game and I will admit one in particular made me paranoid with the atmosphere. Your enemies are fun and the bigger encounters are very difficult to deal with sometimes which I personally like because it means I need to use my squad to it's potential and figure out how to deal with taking or eliminating the objective. The game also uses a shield and health-bar system like Halo: Combat Evolved which I personaly love in games.

This game is totally worth looking into if you're looking for a solid shooter with fun encounters, good weapons, enjoyable squad mechanics and a new look into how the Clone wars were fought. Just don't come for the story because you won't be pleased by how engaging it isn't.

reviewText:
An old game, but possibly one of the best and most enjoyable Star Wars games out there.

PROS:

Story: A great story filled with well-written dialogue and witty comments by your squad mates at times. The voice acting is superb, and really adds to the immersive gameplay. The different personalities of your squadmates, and their periodic jest at each other really adds up to the feeling of coming together with your squad.

Graphics: While the game was released in 2005, the graphics are really not terrible, and were no big deal while I played. For me (and other people I am sure) graphics don't matter as much as a good story or immersiveness. Still, the graphics are pleasing to the eye, the HUD is nice, and the animations are great.

Immersiveness: It may just be me, but from the beginning to the end I found myself extremely immersed into the game at times. From ordering my squadmates around, strategically placing charges and having them cover me, making sure my mates always had enough health, it went on and on throughout the game, which really impressed me. The enviroment is a big key in this factor, from managing large areas with my squad to cover ground or cautiously stalking in a claustrophobic tunnel, it really determined how immersive the game could be.

Squad Mechanics: This is not a game where you can NOT run into a room and expect to kill everything. You need your squad, and your squad needs you. I found very quickly that bulldozing into the next area without any plan whatsoever soon became a terrible idea. Like most older FPS games, this one is brutal. Enemies are difficult to kill without your squads support fire and strategic placement. Something I found interesting is your squad's reactions to cetain events. I was running through a bug tunnel on Geonosis, and I believe one had snuck up behind me, and all of a sudden I hear, Sir! behind you!" It was a very cool mechanic that I thought was unique in a way
date: especially for an older game. (Not saying that old games can't be good in ways that you wouldn't know
recommended: it just surprised me.)\n\nSound:  The sound in this game is fantastic
hoursPlayed:
and the soundtrack fits perfectly with the missions.

In-Between:

Squad A.I: While other people have pointed out that the Squad A.I is

reviewText:
A fantastic game with excellent music and endearing squad humour. In my opinion it has also aged well.

You are Delta 38, leader of the 4-man Delta Team who are clone troopers with advanced equipment and medical implants, as well as more personality to help with creative thinking.
The gameplay mostly revolves around ordering your squad members into positions, which also tells them what weapons to use. Best of all your squad will actually do what you tell them to, even if it gets them taken out. Makes you wonder how Fallout 4 still can't fix companions standing in doorways!

Know that the first area (Geonosis) is the least fun, so stick with it. As you progress the game (slowly) gives you more options, as in there will be more positions than you have squad members, so you will have to make quick decisions while under fire. The pacing gets faster as well, both from more dangerous enemies and more heavy weapons available, but also thanks to good storytelling and use of the loud, epic music this game has.

There are good mods to fix common graphical issues/crashes and allow higher resolutions (I played it in 4K).

Unfortunately it ends on a cliffhanger as it sets up for a sequel that never came.

But yay, Wookie life-debts for everybody!

reviewText:
A first person shooter that revolves around the noble clone trooper, from inception to their major actions on Genosis to Kashyyyk (wookie planet) and through galactic ships follow a story as breif and explosive as the lifes of the main protagonists.

Republic commando, is told from the troopers point of view, they are all clones but it gives a glimps of the uniqeness that is inherent in all the clone troopers, their kinship and a little of the attention to details that make starwars amazing.

Basically, (as played on hardest difficulty) you are in charge of a fourman team, delta squad, of which you are the leading commando and your three 'pod brothers' will be ai controlled interactable teamates.
You must fight your way through levels, utilising your team as you go, weather assigning them to cover, sniping positions and turrets to hacking terminals and smashing doors.
teamwork is essential and rewarding when taking down enemies to clearing areas.
must for the fans.

reviewText:
In my humble opinion, this is one of the, if not THE, best Star Wars FPS games out there. Not only the game itself is awesome, it also shows how badass the Clone Troopers really were.
When you need something done, you call Delta Squad.
Despite the fact that it's pretty old by now, it's amazing both graphically and in gameplay terms.
Great squad AI, linear but solid story, decent graphics and great gameplay.
But, if you're here to play Multiplayer, I've heard that the servers were shut down.

My recommendation? If you're a Star Wars fan, like me, is a MUST HAVE. If not, you can always wait until it's on sale. But, is a very enjoyable game for everyone.

reviewText: A bit difficult, the AI is competent, admittedly the enemy more so than your team. Now, your team are Fixer, Scorch and Sev. You play as Boss. It's tactical, a bit. Order Fixer to pick Sev up off the floor, tell Scorch to bomb a bridge and defend them all simultaneously. It starts on Geonosis, where you have to kill Sun Fac and bomb a droid foundry. Step one was fairly simple. Step to went to hell in a handbasket. The weapon choice is your blaster rifle and your pistol. The only flaw is that some enemies are so armored and deal so much damage it's ridiculous.

reviewText:
In my humble opinion, this is one of the, if not THE, best Star Wars FPS games out there. Not only the game itself is awesome, it also shows how badass the Clone Troopers really were.
When you need something done, you call Delta Squad.
Despite the fact that it's pretty old by now, it's amazing both graphically and in gameplay terms.
Great squad AI, linear but solid story, decent graphics and great gameplay.
But, if you're here to play Multiplayer, I've heard that the servers were shut down.

My recommendation? If you're a Star Wars fan, like me, is a MUST HAVE. If not, you can always wait until it's on sale. But, is a very enjoyable game for everyone.

reviewText:
Star Wars Republic Commando is an fps game released in the star wars universe in 2005. In 2015 it still remains one of the best Star War games ever to be created and im trully sad to admit, i didnt appreciate it in its time of release. Back at the time i felt the game was really hard even on normal and i couldnt get accustomised with the various game mechanics. Now that im a bit older (but certaintly not wiser ^^), i came to appreciate this awesome title in all its grandeur.

In this game you play the leader of a republic commando team, whose purpose is espionage,sabotage and advanced reconnaisssance. Obviously stealth is out of the question for like 95% of the game but the rest are yours for the making. Your team includes 3 more members each specializing in its own field. You get your sniper, your demo man and your enginneer as well. Throughout the game you are called to make tactical decisions and place your team8s around the field, in order to maximize your chances of survival and win your confrontations. Its sounds easy to do and at first it is, but as the game evolves your desicions must evolve as well.  All and all that was one aspect i enjoyed the most in this game.

As with any good fps, you get to use a lot of different weapons and grenades and you can further enchance your own weapons to meet any kind of enemy. From the simple laser pistol to a full rocket launcher, this game has it all and more.
In terms of gameplay difficulty, the game is not as hard as you might think, but its harder that most of todays standard measures. You dont get to do rambo stuff, cause you will be facing the ground and w8 for your m8s to revive you and that is really nervebreaking. All the levels have a linear design as well, so you wont miss your next objective. Maybe for most that is considered a down, but i think it works pretty well for this game.

The graphics arent on par with todays standards, but you can modify the texture pack anyway you like and you can increase the games resolution as well. On the plus side even if you dont it still looks ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. And as with any star wars game that respects itself, the audio is one of the best things in this game. Everything from the tiniest footstep to the biggest blast has been exceptional and thats something i cant say for most games these days.The dialogues are grimm and funny at the same time and the voices seem to match everyone and everything in this game.

All and all i recommend this game to everyone. If you are a fan of fps you will love it, if you are a fan of star wars you will love it even more and even if you dont like fps try it. You will love it too!!!

reviewText:
I recently picked this game up to see if it was actually as good as I remembered it being. (The love of old games is often just a cloud of nostalgia and vague memories from a time when you didn't have anything better to play)
Having just beat the game, I can say beyong all doubt Star Wars: Republic Commando is one of the best Star Wars games ever made.  The graphics are still passable by today's standards, and the controls are quite solid. But where it really shines is the AI.  This is the only single-player game I have ever played that actually managed to feel like it was multiplayer.
Every member of your squad is about as important as you are.  You are not some super-human bullet sponge, you need them to push forward, and often, to clean up the mess when you get yourself killed like an idiot. (About 40-50% of the time, ordering an immediate revive is not a good idea. It just puts your squad in range of enemy fire.)

There are only a few things I didn't like about this game: (#1) There is a mission where they remove your squad.  It sucks. Removing the squad in a squad-based game was not a good idea. (#2) The game ends somewhat abruptly.  It feels like they were intending a sequel that ended up never happening.  And (#3) Very, very rarely, the AI will freak out a little, or the game will think a teammate is dead when they aren't so it won't let you heal them.

Overall, great game. I HIGHLY recommend purchasing it.

reviewText: One of my favorite Star Wars games and favorite First Person Shooters in general, an excellent example of what the universe of the prequel trilogy can be when placed in the right hands.  The campaign mission doesn't exactly tell a compelling story (its 3 narrative arcs broken into smaller missions) and the gameplay can be repetitive, but the whole experience is solid thanks to the squad based combat.  It really feels like you have control over your squad, each combat situation ends up feeling like a puzzle you need to carefully strategize with team placement to solve.  I've beaten this 3 times since the original came out on the Xbox and I will probably play through again at some point, highly recommended, even if it isn't perfect.

reviewText:
STAR WARS: Republic Commando, a video game that takes place between Attack of the Clones and Revenge of the Sith, is an ideal example for a STAR WARS game about ordinary soldiers.  Fun, humorous, and unique, its pros outway its cons, but the problems can still pop up.

Plot:
You are Delta 38, the leader of a group of elite clone commandos working for the republic.  You, along with your team, must do the jobs that are too big to know about and too extreme for a regular clone.  Your team is the greatest weapon you have.  Versatile, yet disfunctional, your squad consist of 07 AKA Sev, a vicious hunter who rarely ever misses, 62 AKA Scorch, the demolitions expert with the maturity of a teenager, and 40 AKA Fixer, your second-in-command and tech head who is serious, yet pure of heart.  They will either cheer for you or jeer at you.  Nevertheless, you four are family, and that's how it will always be.

PROS:
- Good characters you can invest in
- Spectacular wepons
- The squad moves and operates like real life soldiers
- Very funny catchphrases and jeers
- Unique locations
- Distinctive weapons
- Extras are interesting

CONS:
- Not a lot of locations
- Gameplay takes some getting use to
- No controller functionality

reviewText:
This game is fantastic in almost everyway, particular emphasis on ALMOST, as there is one particular part about it that you should consider before getting this game.

But before I do that, let us discuss what is great about this game, which is a lot. For starters, the gameplay in general is nothing short of amazing and gritty. The gunplay between the various different types of weapons (really attachments to one gun that all do different stuff but w/e) is satisfying. Most battles are often ripe with tension thanks to the more or less competant AI.

The game also has a squad system. Wherever you go, you have about three other clones with you to help you out in battle. Like the enemy AI, they can hold their own fine. I especially like how they sometimes go into weird fighting animations with other enemies that they never lose. You can command these troopers to do certain stuff, like blow open doors, hack open doors, take up sniping positions, heal themselves, etc. This provides some level of strategy, though it's usually obvious what you want to do when you do it due to conveinient placement.

Now, if any of your members (including yourself) ends up biting the dust, then you or another member can help them back up. Overall, the system works well enough, and  I reccommend you learn it fast.

Normally, something like this would be good, but the game continues to impress with its characters and story. Just in case none of you know, this game takes place throughout the Clone Wars of the Prequel Films. It centers on Delta Squad, a four-man squad of elite clone troopers, who are genetically modified soldiers. Essentially ten-year trained badasses. However, the different types of personalities between the four all make sense. Boss, the clone you play as, is more or less uptight, but compassionate and caring for his men. Fixer is by-the-book, standard soldier guy. Sev is dark and overall creepy, but you grow to love the guy due to his wisecracking remarks with his fellow squadmates as well as his ruthless combat skills. Finally, there's Scorch, who is hilarious in every way. Throughout the story, you grow to care about them and what they go through, something you wouldn't normally expect from a game focusing on emotionless military badasses.

The story itself is grand, if short (clocks in around 6-7 hours at most.) You get lead through planets like Kashyyk, an abandoned ship, and Geonosis.

Overall, the game is amazing... except for one thing.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This game is unstable as hell. I don't know what it is, but there is a possibilty your game will crash as soon as you make a new game and play the first mission. And when I say that, I mean as your guy literally lands on the ♥♥♥♥ing ground. Fixes have been made for this, but they don't work for me. So take that into consideration.

9/10

reviewText:
Easily one of the best games I have ever played.When I first played this game I didn't even like Star Wars that much,but this game made me a fan.I get goosebumps only when I hear the game's soundtrack.

Gameplay-wise,the game is absolutely beautifully designed.It plays out like a regular shooter game,the guns feel good and you have a decent variety of weapons and enemies.What makes the game stand out,is the tactical element of it.You give orders to your fellow Delta Squad commandos during battle.Knowing where,when and how to control them can make the game easier or harder.Going through the campaign,I never got bored because the game offers enough variety.

The storyline is the icing on the cake.It keeps you engaged and makes you love the characters and the universe that they are in.The personalities in the game are fun,interesting and exciting.

Even the soundtrack is one of the best in any game that I played.

In the end I'd like to express my regrets that we still don't have a sequel for the game...EA please...

Sev,hang in there!

reviewText: A not so long time ago in a country not far far away came a game so good we would ask for a sequel for ten years after release and still has not got one yet. This is star wars Republic Commandos. In the introduction you are shown the early years of a clone through quick clips of training introducing your squad. Your excellently written and acted squad is comprised of Fixer, the hacker and technical expert, Sev who is the hunter and sniper of the group who jokes around with Scorch, the demolitions expert who is always telling jokes at the worst of times. You and your squad fight on iconic planets from the movies such as Geonosis and Kashyyyk doing missons such as killing geonosian leaders, blowing up droid factories and saving wookie generals. The game is a first person shooter (obviously) with some strategy elements involved via squad commands such as ordering your troops to move to tactical positions, provide covering fire, attack targeted enemies and seize objectives. Certain actions will play to a commando's strengths like Sev is the best with a sniper and Scorch arms explosives faster and Fixer hacks quicker. This game looks good even though it came out about a decade ago and has really nice level design. The campaign is short lasting about 5-7 hours but it makes you eager for more and the story set up a sequel which we unfortunately never got but i hope that one day we will. All in all i give this game an 8/10, i would have rated if the campaign was slightly longer.

reviewText:
+ Great clone wars commando troops and squad
+ All 3 squad mates have their own flavor, but aren't exclusive to their speciality (e.g. the demolitions guy isn't the only guy that can undergo demolitions tasks, but he's just faster at them I think)
+ Guns are fun, with your main gun having 3 variations (rapid fire, sniper, anti armor) with a fifth slot for alien guns and a surprisingly superb melee attack
+ lots of chances to use squad tactics and assess sitations to make better calls. you can direct which cover to use and enemies to focus on.
+ squad functions feel fun to use (ordering squad mates around and changing tactics)

~ Graphics are fine. Kind of plain and you fight the same enemies for large chunks of time, but they make good use of it.

- Story is fine overall and closes out at a steady pace, but ends abruptly at a point you feel like more came after.

Overall they really nailed the tight squad combat and made the combat fun. I'd be very interested to see this get another entry.

reviewText: If you like first person shooters and Star Wars, then you will enjoy this game. Simple but intuitive squad commands add depth to the FPS gameplay. The campaign mode doesn't take very long to finish, but it's fun and the commandos are well done characters. Each of them has personality and adds to the squad in a meaningful way. The game does have a multiplayer aspect, but I don't know much about it because I've never played it. Some technical notes; this game runs well on medium to high settings with integrated graphics. I'm running it on an Acer Aspire XC- 603G (a cheap Walmart PC given to me by a family member) and haven't had any issues on medium settings. I played this on the original Xbox back in 2006 and it's a better experience even on a low-end PC. 10/10 did purchase again.

reviewText:
Released in March 22, 2005 this first person Star Wars game is probably the best thing about the prequel films. In this game you are 1 of many clones being trained to be Commando's of the Republic on Kamino. Basically the Republic Commandos are the Navy Seals of the Star wars universe. The game takes place during Episode 2: The Clone Wars and is supposed to bridge the gap between Ep2 and Ep3. I always found this game awesome because of the perspective. What I mean by that is that most star wars games always focus on the Jedi or you are this master sith lord or something that gives you an advantage over the others. While in this game it gives you a soldiers perspective of the Clone Wars, which was greatly overlooked during the films. You play as the leader of Delta Squad; a 4 man expertly trained group each with special abilities and skill sets. Sev is the Sniper, Fixer is the hacker, Scorch is the demolitions expert and you... well you are simply the Boss. Although the game emphasizes that each has special ability sets, anyone of your group can do the task you tell them todo. The game is one of the first games that I know of that puts you in control of AI. For example if you see a vantage point you can call out one of the commandos to snipe over there, or if you notice one member is low on health you may send them off to heal. This mechanic brings a variety of ways to play the game but also makes you actually feel like the leader of this squad. Each of the characters in my opinion each have their own personality that doesnt make them dull or boring and makes you want to care for them. The game starts you off on an assassination mission on Geonosis but then leads to other planets like Kashyyyk and broken down space carriers. I personally loved the campaign because you are only a soldier so alot of the time you are just as curious of the mission as they are. The game has great combat with a variety of weapons and a fair difficulty level that you can change at any time. The grittiness that this game brings to the star wars universe is awesome and is defiantly  a must play for any Star Wars fan that can find a original Xbox copy or buys it for $10 off Steam.

OVERALL:

This game is a great first person shooter that takes place in the star wars universe and should be played by anyone who enjoys that. Also the game has team deathmatch multiplayer so if you are into that sort of thing you should play now before the servers shut down!

9/10

reviewText: A Star Wars FPS that has no no force or even lightsabres? But somehow one of the best Star Wars games out there? Indeed it is, believe it or not. This is a squad based shooter but you can go through the entire game without needing to command your squad all the time. Despite this however their AI actually works. The multiplayer brings back so many memories. While the official servers are no longer a thing, there are still some third party servers around so look out for them but once you do, you'll no doubt have plenty of fun. Sadly Delta Squad, despite a small cameo in the Clone Wars cartoon, have since been completly forgotten about which is a real shame. Pick up this game, it's aged brilliantly and still plays well and is probably the best thing to come out of the prequels.

Easily one of the best games I have ever played.When I first played this game I didn't even like Star Wars that much,but this game made me a fan.I get goosebumps only when I hear the game's soundtrack.

Gameplay-wise,the game is absolutely beautifully designed.It plays out like a regular shooter game,the guns feel good and you have a decent variety of weapons and enemies.What makes the game stand out,is the tactical element of it.You give orders to your fellow Delta Squad commandos during battle.Knowing where,when and how to control them can make the game easier or harder.Going through the campaign,I never got bored because the game offers enough variety.

The storyline is the icing on the cake.It keeps you engaged and makes you love the characters and the universe that they are in.The personalities in the game are fun,interesting and exciting.

Even the soundtrack is one of the best in any game that I played.

In the end I'd like to express my regrets that we still don't have a sequel for the game...EA please...

reviewText:
I recently picked this game up to see if it was actually as good as I remembered it being. (The love of old games is often just a cloud of nostalgia and vague memories from a time when you didn't have anything better to play)
Having just beat the game, I can say beyong all doubt Star Wars: Republic Commando is one of the best Star Wars games ever made.  The graphics are still passable by today's standards, and the controls are quite solid. But where it really shines is the AI.  This is the only single-player game I have ever played that actually managed to feel like it was multiplayer.
Every member of your squad is about as important as you are.  You are not some super-human bullet sponge, you need them to push forward, and often, to clean up the mess when you get yourself killed like an idiot. (About 40-50% of the time, ordering an immediate revive is not a good idea. It just puts your squad in range of enemy fire.)

There are only a few things I didn't like about this game: (#1) There is a mission where they remove your squad.  It sucks. Removing the squad in a squad-based game was not a good idea. (#2) The game ends somewhat abruptly.  It feels like they were intending a sequel that ended up never happening.  And (#3) Very, very rarely, the AI will freak out a little, or the game will think a teammate is dead when they aren't so it won't let you heal them.

Overall, great game. I HIGHLY recommend purchasing it.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic in almost everyway, particular emphasis on ALMOST, as there is one particular part about it that you should consider before getting this game.

But before I do that, let us discuss what is great about this game, which is a lot. For starters, the gameplay in general is nothing short of amazing and gritty. The gunplay between the various different types of weapons (really attachments to one gun that all do different stuff but w/e) is satisfying. Most battles are often ripe with tension thanks to the more or less competant AI.

The game also has a squad system. Wherever you go, you have about three other clones with you to help you out in battle. Like the enemy AI, they can hold their own fine. I especially like how they sometimes go into weird fighting animations with other enemies that they never lose. You can command these troopers to do certain stuff, like blow open doors, hack open doors, take up sniping positions, heal themselves, etc. This provides some level of strategy, though it's usually obvious what you want to do when you do it due to conveinient placement.

Now, if any of your members (including yourself) ends up biting the dust, then you or another member can help them back up. Overall, the system works well enough, and  I reccommend you learn it fast.

Normally, something like this would be good, but the game continues to impress with its characters and story. Just in case none of you know, this game takes place throughout the Clone Wars of the Prequel Films. It centers on Delta Squad, a four-man squad of elite clone troopers, who are genetically modified soldiers. Essentially ten-year trained badasses. However, the different types of personalities between the four all make sense. Boss, the clone you play as, is more or less uptight, but compassionate and caring for his men. Fixer is by-the-book, standard soldier guy. Sev is dark and overall creepy, but you grow to love the guy due to his wisecracking remarks with his fellow squadmates as well as his ruthless combat skills. Finally, there's Scorch, who is hilarious in every way. Throughout the story, you grow to care about them and what they go through, something you wouldn't normally expect from a game focusing on emotionless military badasses.

The story itself is grand, if short (clocks in around 6-7 hours at most.) You get lead through planets like Kashyyk, an abandoned ship, and Geonosis.

Overall, the game is amazing... except for one thing.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This game is unstable as hell. I don't know what it is, but there is a possibilty your game will crash as soon as you make a new game and play the first mission. And when I say that, I mean as your guy literally lands on the ♥♥♥♥ing ground. Fixes have been made for this, but they don't work for me. So take that into consideration.

9/10

reviewText: If the not-huge variety and smegtacularly irritating epilogue doesn’t annoy you, then Republic Commando makes for a high-quality FPS that deserves its place in Star Wars canon. Hell, being able to shoot off the heads of battle droids is worth the entry price. The only other real problem is that it doesn’t last very long, with just the three big missions in as many different locations to complete, and whatever multiplayer capabilities it once had are likely unsupported nowadays. In fact, Steam eerily informed me that I played the game for precisely 9.6 hours, which isn’t too much. Nevertheless, what little time it takes to finish will be chock-full of excitement, and finishing Hard will take some doing, so there’s undoubtedly replay value present. Find it for a fiver on whatever platform takes your fancy and you’ll be entirely happy with your dark, tactics-driven laser-fest.

reviewText:
Clear Space Hulks, blow up vital bridges, and play a vital (if now unrecognized) role in a war you were born to fight as a member of the elite Delta Squad!

The game itself is quite old, and unfortunately has not aged as well as most. However, if you're a die-hard Star Wars fan, a classic FPS connoisseur, or a nostalgia junkie, this is well worth the now discounted price of admission.

Multiplayer via Gamespy is dead (and has been for years, as most of you already know), but Multiplayer via direct-connect servers or Gameranger are available (If that's your thing).

Regardless, If you're itching for something old, with maybe a little bit of mold attached, look no further!

reviewText:
+ Great clone wars commando troops and squad
+ All 3 squad mates have their own flavor, but aren't exclusive to their speciality (e.g. the demolitions guy isn't the only guy that can undergo demolitions tasks, but he's just faster at them I think)
+ Guns are fun, with your main gun having 3 variations (rapid fire, sniper, anti armor) with a fifth slot for alien guns and a surprisingly superb melee attack
+ lots of chances to use squad tactics and assess sitations to make better calls. you can direct which cover to use and enemies to focus on.
+ squad functions feel fun to use (ordering squad mates around and changing tactics)

~ Graphics are fine. Kind of plain and you fight the same enemies for large chunks of time, but they make good use of it.

- Story is fine overall and closes out at a steady pace, but ends abruptly at a point you feel like more came after.

Overall they really nailed the tight squad combat and made the combat fun. I'd be very interested to see this get another entry.

reviewText: Star Wars Republic Commando, Knights of the Old Republic, and Battlefront 1 are considered the Holy Trinity of Star Wars games.  You can put Rogue Squadron in there as well, but these three are always the ones everyone always talks about.  Republic Commando is an FPS set during the period of the Clone Wars where you command an elite clone unit called Delta Squad.  As you travel throughout the galaxy and undergo missions you will be faced with very difficult challenges, very immersive gameplay, and a cast of characters you will never forget.  This is a no-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t game.  It's hard, it's fun, and it leaves you begging for more.  I remember this game came out during the time of Halo 1 and after playing both I thought Republic Commando just kicked way much more ♥♥♥.  This is a game you must play if you're a Star Wars fan or an FPS fan.  You will be hooked right as soon as you give your squad that first BREACH THAT DOOR" command.\n\nI'm giving this game a strong 9.5/10."

reviewText:
Released in March 22, 2005 this first person Star Wars game is probably the best thing about the prequel films. In this game you are 1 of many clones being trained to be Commando's of the Republic on Kamino. Basically the Republic Commandos are the Navy Seals of the Star wars universe. The game takes place during Episode 2: The Clone Wars and is supposed to bridge the gap between Ep2 and Ep3. I always found this game awesome because of the perspective. What I mean by that is that most star wars games always focus on the Jedi or you are this master sith lord or something that gives you an advantage over the others. While in this game it gives you a soldiers perspective of the Clone Wars, which was greatly overlooked during the films. You play as the leader of Delta Squad; a 4 man expertly trained group each with special abilities and skill sets. Sev is the Sniper, Fixer is the hacker, Scorch is the demolitions expert and you... well you are simply the Boss. Although the game emphasizes that each has special ability sets, anyone of your group can do the task you tell them todo. The game is one of the first games that I know of that puts you in control of AI. For example if you see a vantage point you can call out one of the commandos to snipe over there, or if you notice one member is low on health you may send them off to heal. This mechanic brings a variety of ways to play the game but also makes you actually feel like the leader of this squad. Each of the characters in my opinion each have their own personality that doesnt make them dull or boring and makes you want to care for them. The game starts you off on an assassination mission on Geonosis but then leads to other planets like Kashyyyk and broken down space carriers. I personally loved the campaign because you are only a soldier so alot of the time you are just as curious of the mission as they are. The game has great combat with a variety of weapons and a fair difficulty level that you can change at any time. The grittiness that this game brings to the star wars universe is awesome and is defiantly  a must play for any Star Wars fan that can find a original Xbox copy or buys it for $10 off Steam.

OVERALL:

This game is a great first person shooter that takes place in the star wars universe and should be played by anyone who enjoys that. Also the game has team deathmatch multiplayer so if you are into that sort of thing you should play now before the servers shut down!

9/10

As well, when you, or one of your teamates dies, they dont die, as such, instead they are incapacitated, and you/they can be revived, so if you die it's not a case NOOOOOOOO!" it's "PLEASSEE DONT DIE AND SCREW THIS UP GUYS" 10/10 get the game

reviewText: Although at first glance this game seems like it is a waste of any money at all, especially coming out near the attack of the clone game, it is one of the best star wars games I have played. This is my second favorite star wars shooter, barley falling below BattleFront 2. The Story is amazing, the atmosphere makes you feel like a badass, while at the same time feeling so weak and fragile. (Especially when fighting Super Battle Droids) This game is a must with either friends or being alone, as the AI will follow orders and even in today's standards are smart and think well. The HUD idea is great, it gives the look as if you are the clone itself. The graphics hold well, and the combat is spectacular. After playing this, you will have a craving for a sequel, and want to have a higher standard in today's shooter games. 10 out of 10. I enjoyed getting this game while being on sale.

reviewText:
I recently picked this game up to see if it was actually as good as I remembered it being. (The love of old games is often just a cloud of nostalgia and vague memories from a time when you didn't have anything better to play)
Having just beat the game, I can say beyong all doubt Star Wars: Republic Commando is one of the best Star Wars games ever made.  The graphics are still passable by today's standards, and the controls are quite solid. But where it really shines is the AI.  This is the only single-player game I have ever played that actually managed to feel like it was multiplayer.
Every member of your squad is about as important as you are.  You are not some super-human bullet sponge, you need them to push forward, and often, to clean up the mess when you get yourself killed like an idiot. (About 40-50% of the time, ordering an immediate revive is not a good idea. It just puts your squad in range of enemy fire.)

There are only a few things I didn't like about this game: (#1) There is a mission where they remove your squad.  It sucks. Removing the squad in a squad-based game was not a good idea. (#2) The game ends somewhat abruptly.  It feels like they were intending a sequel that ended up never happening.  And (#3) Very, very rarely, the AI will freak out a little, or the game will think a teammate is dead when they aren't so it won't let you heal them.

Overall, great game. I HIGHLY recommend purchasing it.

reviewText:
A fantastic game with excellent music and endearing squad humour. In my opinion it has also aged well.

You are Delta 38, leader of the 4-man Delta Team who are clone troopers with advanced equipment and medical implants, as well as more personality to help with creative thinking.
The gameplay mostly revolves around ordering your squad members into positions, which also tells them what weapons to use. Best of all your squad will actually do what you tell them to, even if it gets them taken out. Makes you wonder how Fallout 4 still can't fix companions standing in doorways!

Know that the first area (Geonosis) is the least fun, so stick with it. As you progress the game (slowly) gives you more options, as in there will be more positions than you have squad members, so you will have to make quick decisions while under fire. The pacing gets faster as well, both from more dangerous enemies and more heavy weapons available, but also thanks to good storytelling and use of the loud, epic music this game has.

There are good mods to fix common graphical issues/crashes and allow higher resolutions (I played it in 4K).

Unfortunately it ends on a cliffhanger as it sets up for a sequel that never came.

But yay, Wookie life-debts for everybody!

reviewText: If you like first person shooters and Star Wars, then you will enjoy this game. Simple but intuitive squad commands add depth to the FPS gameplay. The campaign mode doesn't take very long to finish, but it's fun and the commandos are well done characters. Each of them has personality and adds to the squad in a meaningful way. The game does have a multiplayer aspect, but I don't know much about it because I've never played it. Some technical notes; this game runs well on medium to high settings with integrated graphics. I'm running it on an Acer Aspire XC- 603G (a cheap Walmart PC given to me by a family member) and haven't had any issues on medium settings. I played this on the original Xbox back in 2006 and it's a better experience even on a low-end PC. 10/10 did purchase again.

reviewText:
TLDR: I love this game above all others, and when you're done with it several times, I'm confident you will too.

Again, not really good at writing reviews. I will however state that I absolutely love this game.
Don't let the few hours clocked on Steam fool you. I only bought it on Steam because it's more convenient than using 2 very worn CDs.
I've played the campaign at least a dozen times over the years. Sadly, the campaign is short, but in no way does the campaign length negatively impact the absolute quality of this game.
Best squad-shooter I've ever played. Excellent voice acting. Squadmate lines are witty and charming, and the squad is extremely affable. There is no way you will not like all of them, though it is very likely that you'll have a favourite. Mine is Scorch :)
And you will experience true loneliness when you and your squad split up on several occasions to achieve independent objectives.

Again, I love this game above all others and I would recommend this game to anyone, anyday and everyday, Star Wars fan or otherwise.

If you value exellent gameplay, simple yet elegant squad mechanics, amazing voice acting, witty one-liners, affable teammates, dark and immersive atmosphere, brilliant music and everything else that makes an excellent game excellent, you would be severely amiss to let this game go unplayed. And when you're done with it, play it again. And again.
One play through hardly does the game justice as it impossible to get take notice of all the gems it offers with just one play through.

Infinity/10.

Clone Advisor: Delta Squad

reviewText:
Star Wars Republic Commando (or as I like to call it also, Band of Clone Bros) is the forgotten and underrated Star Wars video game that everybody that loves the Star Wars franchise should play. The story of the game is based on the 2nd and 3rd movies of the prequel trilogy, where you play as the leader of a Spec Ops squad of 4 Clones of the Galactic Republic who are responsible for performing special missions that occure behind the scenes of the Clone Wars. This is a squad based game, where using your squad team seriously will be your road for victory. The fact that you play as a Clone, fighting along aside with a team of other Clones, breaks the monotony of the usual protagonists of a story of a Star Wars game, which tend to be Jedis, Siths or some random bounty hunter.

I agree, like the vast majority of people who played it, that this is a good game - but not a perfect one. It has one problem that I felt frustrated about: while the enemy was agressive against you, your squad team will be very weak and will lack agressivness, unless you babysit them all the time. Sometimes, they will just get close to an enemy and try killing them by melee (it reminds me of the Warscape Engine BS that is now plaguing the Total War series...), instead of trying to get to cover by their own initiative. Another problem  that I have with the game is the lack of variety with the level designs: the game is divided only by 3 chapters, which are limited equally to 3 areas (first you fight in one planet, then inside a ship, and then again in another planet). A little bit of more effort from the producers of this videogame could have created more variety for you to be present in another scenarios/planets of the Clone Wars. But I believe this problem to be minor, when you compare to the much more positive aspects of the game.

Still, I cannot recommend you buy it at full price (except if your are a Star Wars nerd :P), since it is an old game and it no longer has an active multiplayermode. Buy it only when it´s in promotion.

Like many people claim, this game really needs a sequel - where you play as the same squad team, now part of the forces of the eeeeeeeevil Galactic Empire. It would have been a much better sequel to make instead of the disaster that was Star Wars BattleFront" EA (THE GAME IS NOT WORTH OF DESERVING OF "BATTELFRONT" ON IT´S TITLE!!!). Unfortunatelly
date:
this game appears to have been forgotten and I don´t think a sequel (or a reboot) will ever be created.

7.5 out of 10
"

reviewText: If you're a fan of FPS's and Star Wars, this is the game for you. It's great fun bossing around your fellow troopers, having a complicated battle strategy and it really makes you feel like you're operating your own team of commandos. However, it can get very boring at times, probably because I don't like single-player FPSs. After hours and hours of plowing down B1s with your assault and wasting several clips of sniper ammo on the B2s, it does lose its entertainment value and just becomes another FPS. However, it can still be fun if you play it correctly.

reviewText: Alright, this game is AWESOME.  Star Wars Republic Commando is an FPS based on the lives of Delta Squad, 4 elite clone commandos who are sent on the most dangerous and imperative missions the republic has to offer.  Each one has his own distinct personality and all 4 of them (you play as squad leader) are pretty likable characters.  Here are the commandos in order:\n\n38 three-eight" aka "Boss" or "Sir"- the squad leader and the player character. He is fully voiced by Temuera Morrison
date: the voice actor for Boba and Jango Fett in the films.  38 (said literally "three-eight")  is a no nonsense commander with a head for strategy and a dry sense of humor.  He leads the squad (obviously) and is able to issue orders to the other 3 commandos
hoursPlayed: he can tell them to set up sniper positions
voteText: anti armor
helpfulPercent: mount turrets
votesHelpful: use healing stations
votesTotal: etc.  (btw these are actual game mechanics
votesFunny: issueing orders to your squad is a huge part of the game).  He has all the weapons that the other 3 commandos are capable of wielding but unlike the others he is capable of using special
commentsCount: enemy weapons that can be found off certain foes.\n\n40 "four-oh" aka "Fixer"- Fixer is the tech specialist of the squad and specialises in hacking and computer interfaces
column16: he is very useful for hacking terminals.  While all the commandos have the same skills and abilities
column17: some are better than others at certain things.  For example
column18: Fixer can hack faster than the others
column19: Scorch is more accurate with grenades and can set explosives faster and Sev is a deadeye with a sniper rifle.  Fixer takes his job verrry seriously and doesn't talk about much other than the mission or how to accomplish it
column20: but he does have moments where he loosens up.  Fixer is exceptional at melee combat and dispatches melee using foes with ease.\n\n62 "six-two" aka "Scorch"-  Scorch is the squad demolitionist and explosive expert and his outlook on life relfects that.  He loves danger and has a very positive
column21: optimistic viewpoint on any sitution
column22: using humor to deal with even the most harrowing of missions.  He is the squad funny guy and his upbeat personality is definitely helpful when things look grim.  Scorch's preferred weapon of choice is the anti-armor grenade launcher and grenades themselves.\n\n07 "oh-seven" aka "Sev"-  Sev is the designated marksman and stealth fighter of the squad and revels in war and battle.  He is a deadly sniper and the best shot in the squad (other than the player).  He is probably the most mandalorian out of the squad and by that I mean he lives for war.  62 finds his fervor for killing to be a bit creepy at times but he is a good soldier and a good friend... and a truly terrible enemy.  Sev's weapon of choice is the sniper rifle
column23: which he uses with pinpoint accuracy.\n\nThe game's combat is pretty good and the squad AI is amazing even for today
column24:
the commandos feel very human and real.  The game even has multiplayer which I'm not sure if there is anyone on it anymore but it was good in its own way as well.

The story is pretty good and involving and gets pretty hectic at times which keeps things interesting.

All in all this is one of the best star wars games out there and I highly reccomend it for any star wars fan.  I know I spent most of this review talking about the characters

reviewText:
This, in my personal opinon, is the best Star Wars game in the entire collection even to date. This game is rich in story, has great character build, and actually has a lot of content for a game that is going on 11 years old. I played this game when I was younger on the original Xbox console, and replaying it on my PC was amazing. I love this game and all its glory even to this date. You should definately play the game.

Pros:Story rich
Beautiful character design and art style (even though the graphics are outdated seeing as this game came out in 2005)
Quite a bit of content
Voice actors feel natural and make the funny/serious dialogue in the game so much better
Quite a bit of enemy variety
Location varierty
Funny dialogue
Cons:Slight glitches with character movement ocasinally
Sometimes some of the AI within the game don't target you as quickly as they should
Sometimes Delta Squad doesn't listen to comands (happened twice through my entire 8.5 hours)
Overall, this game is a ton of fun even today, and the game is worth picking up when on a sale or if you happen to have a spare $10 in your Steam wallet.
11/10 Seriously, the game is that much fun.

reviewText:
I bought this game on release and for years since I've always wanted to go back and play it again, but I could never remember why until I bought it again. Despite having to jump through numerous hoops in order to get it optimised for a modern operating system, Republic Commando is a surprisingly wonderful game given that it is, in many ways, a rather standard corridor shooter.

Whilst genre-wise it may play as a rather standard FPS shooter, the writing of the characters and the missions gives a much greater depth to the world than it otherwise ought to have. You play the commander of a crack team of Republic commandos, and your teammates all have distinct and consistent personalities, and are autonomous enough to make them seem genuinely intelligent. Yes, you will be giving orders for the most part - and their AI is programmed well enough so as to feel like they're an extension of yourself, as they should - but you won't need to tell them to heal themselves, or attack the bad guys if a threat looms, and should you be overcome and you need help, they will be promptly at your side healing you at the risk of their own lives. And this all helps to develop a genuine bond with your fellow squadmates, particularly as the game is much easier when you have their help, further emphasising the importance of your cumulative strength as a team.

On top of this, the missions, whilst comprising of many parts, manage to consistently escalate the stakes until by the end of the mission you feel a genuine and frantic rush of adrenaline as you plunge headlong into the final stages of each operation. And it's the little things that make a difference - for example, whereas most games would have an alert announcement indicating that your vessel will self-destruct, in this case they're serious. And it's these little things that actually make you emote as a player, which is what any experience should do, whether it's a book or a movie or a video game.

And thus, Republic Commando manages to rise above it's state and hold up quite well as a challenging and compelling experience.

I'd recommend it to Star Wars fans primarily, although I think it has a wider appeal because of the quality of the writing.

Yes, you will be giving orders for the most part - and their AI is programmed well enough so as to feel like they're an extension of yourself, as they should - but you won't need to tell them to heal themselves, or attack the bad guys if a threat looms, and should you be overcome and you need help, they will be promptly at your side healing you at the risk of their own lives. reviewText:
Republic Commando is a tactical first person shooter where you are the leader of a small squad called Delta Squad. The gameplay is much like any other shooter however instead of run and gun the player must order their squadmates to perform different functions such as slice a terminal, set a bomb and get behind cover and use various weapons including sniper, anti-armor and grenade. They will also target one enemy, form up on the player, go to a certain location or search and destroy. On top of that the player has a special weapon called the DC-17 which was interchangeable from assault rifle to sniper rifle to anti-armor launcher. The Player also had a full HUD that made it feel like the player was really in a clone trooper helmet.

One of the other cooler features is instead of dying you just go down and you can either call a squadmate over to revive you, maintain their orders and kill everything before getting you or just reload a save.  A lot of these features worked perfectly it isn’t like whoever could develop the sequel couldn’t just use all these features all over again. It begs the question where is the sequel if the gameplay mechanics are already there and ready to be used again.

You are Delta RC-1138 or “Boss,” the leader of Delta squad who has in it RC-1262, “Scorch,” the comedic relief /explosives expert, RC-1140, “Fixer,” the by the book soldier that specializes in slicing and RC-1207, “Sev,” the hunter/sniper. You start out in your birthing tube on Kamino and it shows your training as you age. Eventually your squad meets up for the invasion of Geonosis during the beginning of the clone wars. There Delta Squad is tasked to infiltrate and assassinate Sun Fac, a Geonosian leader. Along with that they have several other objectives that they accomplish including destroying an underground droid factory and retrieving launch codes from a Trade Federation core ship.
One year after the invasion of Geonosis Delta Squad is set to investigate their original ship the Prosecutor to find out why it has not responded in several weeks. During this they find out the Trandoshan Slaves and Mercenaries have taken over the ship with the help of the Separatists in order to capture and bring the ship back to a Separatist base. Delta Squad ends up destroying all of the Trandoshans and defends the ship from a Trade Federation Battleship that attacks shortly after.

The final mission involves Delta Squad being the advance recon team on Kashyyyk and to help the Wookiees to fight back the Trandoshan Slavers and Separatists that have control of the planet. They end up rescuing General Tarfful and run into General Grievous themselves but only end up fighting those IG-100 Magna Guards that carry the Electrostaff. Eventually Delta Squad makes it to where the Separatist Battleship has linked itself the giant citadel tree and they destroy it. They end the game on a cliffhanger as Sev had been captured and the invasion of Kashyyyk by the main republic force had begun which once again begs the question, why not continue the story and have a sequel.

Now the graphics aren’t anything to write home about but they are fairly impressive for when this game was made, 2005, but what really makes this game look impressive is the HUD for the clone troopers and the art assets they created for the game. Lucasarts did not separate themselves from canon too much in that the story of Delta Squad lines up perfectly with that of the actual Star Wars universe and Extended Universe.
Republic Commando is actually the first Star Wars game that featured licensed music that included the song “Clones” by the band Ash which sounds awesome. On top of that they included all of the heavy battle music from John Williams you may have heard from any of the other Star Wars movies. The voice acting is also superb as for most of the clone troopers and Delta 38 was voiced by the original actor for Jango Fett, Temuera Morrison which I thought was a nice touch.

Overall this game is actually one of my favorite Star Wars games of all time and is an absolute classic in terms of story and gameplay. With the disbandment of Lucasarts, in order to make a sequel some developer is going to have to get rights to both the Star Wars IP and the Republic Commando IP which could make it quite pricey.
•	Story  - 4 out of 5
•	Gameplay – 4 out of 5
•	Graphics – 4 out of 5
•	Sound  - 5 out of 5
•	Fun – 5 out of 5
Pros:
-	Fun gameplay/squad commanding
-	Great music and voice acting
-	Star Wars Universe
Cons:
-	Can get annoyingly difficult with the lack of ammo at times
-	Repetitive enemies
I’m giving a Total score of 90%
